novel_text:
The apes came down on a Tuesday, beating shields that rang like pothole covers and clattering through the rust-laced gates as if sound could be a kind of weapon. People ducked, dogs bayed, and someone’s laundry—a string of shirts the same rust-red as the gates—became the first wave’s trophy. Nobody died; nobody ever did during those raids, not in our quarter. There was a method to it, Mara Quill thought as she peered through the split curtains of 49 Ingres Lane and saw the column pass. Every ape chose a shirt, but never two. Every ape paused at the same cracked paving stone and thumped it once with a knuckle as big as her notary stamp. Then they made right angles where alleys offered curves.

She took notes because she took notes about everything. When nothing was happening, she inventively found meaning in sprinklers and cookie sales and whether the new man in 57 was really a gardener or a soldier, and when something did happen, when armored apes trod laundry and shattered a jar of pickled cabbage in an artful arc like cherry blossoms, she became steady and sweet inside with alertness. She wrote on a recipe card because the notebook she kept for raids had walked off last week; she’d probably lent it to someone who had insisted they would return it. People did say things.

“Dear,” she called over her shoulder, because it was a habit and because it comforted her to say it even if no one answered, “please see how they are touching that same crack. If that isn’t weird, I need new definitions.”

No one answered. There had been no “dear” for some time now, just the plant in the sink and the constant smell of binder clip metal and ink and an embarrassment of saucers because she kept finding them at yard sales and no one else seemed to want them. They hung like pale moons along the kitchen shelf, and there were too many to use in a lifetime. Her neighbors had opinions about that, as neighbors do.

Mara had other tools, too, tucked under the dishcloths: a bone-handled letter opener that might actually have been a knife, a small wooden device for pressing wax seals that she had only once used to press cinnamon into toast, and the thing that had altered her posture, her days, the way she saw her own hands.

She had called it—because it came with no label and because the man who gave it to her had a cough that ended in “eh, what?”—the infinate stabler, which was what he seemed to call it in the letter, all smudged and mad with pencil.

There are objects that you pick up and mistake for their cousins; you think a river pebble is a gumdrop. You think a long bone is a walking stick. This was a stapler in the way that a rake is a fork, a since-when tool. It had weight like a word you should not use and a grip that did not grip your palm so much as slide into your hand as if the hand had been made for it, not the other way around. Its jaw could open the span of a loaf pan, but its bite was delicate enough to kiss two curls of paper together and make them whole.

It made a sound when you used it: not click, not clack, but almost a sigh, like a seam finding itself. It did not run out of staples. Or if it did, the world did not live long enough to see that day. And if it were only a stapler, Mara would have used it to staple everything, which she did anyway: she stapled raffia to the fence when it came loose and stapled a peony’s heavy head to a bamboo stick when the weather made it bow. She stapled a hem, and she stapled a cough, and she was only ashamed about one of those things. She pressed the jaw over her left thumbnail once and it made the smooth press of pressure and there was no pain and afterward, the nail shone like she had polished it with lemon.

“But what are the apes stapling?” she asked the empty room as the column marched past. The apes’ tusked helmets had ancient scratches in them, stories arranged in parallel lines, and their cloaks looked like stitched pelts of something that had grown in a bramble. They were never dirty. They had ritual dirt, of course; they smeared it on their cheeks the way children touched dabs of paint. Their leader—three leaders?—raised a spear that was more a pointer than a weapon and jabbed it into air on each corner.

Her neighbor, Bram from 73, said a spear is a sentence, and a shield is a book, but he said many things. He used to be a shepherd or so he said, in the hills beyond, where the apes came from if you believed the maps. Mara believed maps like she believed recipes: nice starting points until someone sensible improved them.

She scribbled: apes touch crack: not random; shirts not socks; no bread stolen; took yard glider last time (why? for what?). Underneath, in smaller letters, she wrote: talk to Bram.

By the time she got her coat—there had been a cold that hung on like a person without a watch—and stepped out, the apes had passed and the street was less a street and more a commentary on noise. Someone cried about the jar. Somebody else laughed because the jar had contained the worst pickled cabbage in a generation and the apes had done a community service. Mara paused at the cracked stone.

It was just a crack in a stone. It ran like a river on a map, and when she traced it with her finger, she felt a coolness, as if wind had been pressed there. She tried to lift the stone. The stone stayed. She took the infinate stabler from her coat pocket because this was that kind of day and because curiosity is a kind of oath and because she knew people were watching and she liked that a little more than she let on, and pressed the open jaw over the crack.

“Just to see,” she said.

The stabler made its sigh, and the crack became a line. The line became nothing. The stone was whole, unbroken, as if freshly poured, as if someone had turned back the day before the day it cracked.

A boy whistled. Bram, who had been in the doorway of 73 working a cigarette he never lit, stepped off his stoop as if he’d been waiting for her. He had hair like a broom that had been used, then washed, then used again, and the narrow look of a person who spent time noticing shadows so he could step in or out of them at the right moment.

“I told you not to do that in public,” he said.

“You told me to tie down the world if it flapped,” Mara said, not lifting the stabler, keeping it in her hand because otherwise it seemed to disappear where she put it, which was a thing that freaked her out and did not freak her out, both.

“I said nothing like that,” Bram said, “but let’s pretend I did and that I am clever for it. That crack—how long do you think it was there?”

“Since the quake,” she said, and when he made a face she added, “or since before the quake. There’s always a before.”

“Some cracks you want. They tell you where not to step. Some news is kind in that way,” he said, but his eyes were on the street, on the same path the apes had taken, on the spots where they’d paused. He stepped to the nearest stoop and knocked with his knuckles; the old woman who lived there shook her head, already knowing, and pushed out a broom so he could sweep the spilled cabbage into a polite hill.

“Are you thrumming?” Mara asked, which was code for Are you listening to something invisible?

“Mm,” Bram said. His ear had a sore spot where it pinched in and held onto the world. He crouched and touched the stone that had been cracked and pressed his palm flat to it. “You patched it. They’ll either be disappointed or impressed.”

“They who?”

“Them,” Bram said, and then laughed at himself because he hated how he sounded when he said things like that. “You know. The apes. I don’t think they like broken things. It throws them. They march on top of seams because they like to know where the seams are. See? It’s a flock thing.”

“A what thing,” Mara said, even though she had heard him say that word before and had chosen to pretend he hadn’t.

“Nothing,” Bram said, and pinched the bridge of his nose as if the world had spilled too bright. He looked at her hand, at the weight of metal resting like a threat or a blessing in her palm. “You’re going to get asked to do something with that. If not today, then tomorrow. I’d prefer you didn’t say yes without telling me.”

“I didn’t say yes to anything,” Mara said, and then caught herself, because she had said yes to everything that ever knocked on her door.

Later, after the street had returned to its usual business of being watched and being repaired and being watched being repaired, she went to Bram’s because he brewed coffee in a pot you had to coax over the stove and it tasted like something dangerous and old. His room smelled like wet wool that had been allowed to sing, which made no sense when she told anybody else, so she didn’t, not anymore. He had a rack of walking sticks that had the same notch carved into each, and photographs where the sky looked heavier than any sky she had seen.

“They’ll come again in three days,” he said, laying out cups, and because Mara watched him like she watched everything, she noticed he always set an extra cup down and then thought better of it and put it back, like the person he hoped would come never did. “And not here. They’ll go to the ring market, to the clay arcades.”

“That’s where the spice sellers put their tables and the locksmith with the pretty son has the cart for his brass shapes,” Mara said. “We can’t have them taking keys. Everyone’d be locked out. The locksmith would be drunk on business and then ashamed of being so happy about why.”

Bram grunted. “They won’t take keys. They don’t like pockets. Keys go in pockets, and they are not, by nature, pocket people.”

“People,” Mara said, to see if he would argue with it.

Bram took his time. He carried the pot to the table and poured.

“You know the trouble with obvious truths?” he asked, settling. “They settle in you so deep you can’t spit them out. Every child in this city can draw you an ape: the brow, the fists, the way they bend from the waist when they run. They can tell you how to scare one with a bell or a cunning cat. They can tell you how the first Legions came across the iron seam that runs from quarry to sea, and how they learned to stack their shields into steps. And they will have never in their lives watched one eat.”

Mara stirred her coffee, which needed no stirring; it didn’t need milk, either, but she liked the swirl.

“Are you about to talk about grass?” she asked.

Bram’s mouth twitched. “I am about to talk about mouths. About teeth. Did you see the leader’s smile today? Did you see the shape of his pupils?”

“Did you see me looking directly into the mouth of the leader of the apes? I prefer to keep the parts of me that are arranged as they are arranged,” she said. “No, Bram. Why don’t you tell me about pupils.”

“They weren’t round,” he said. “They were—then again, I forget where you grew up. Maybe you didn’t have the hills. Maybe you never went out when the fog lifts and the ewes are calling their lambs in the gullies and the sky is eating the last of the night. Maybe you never looked an animal in the eye and learned what it was by the shape of the light it let in. Rectangles. Did you know? Like doors.”

He looked, for a second, like the boy he had once been. It came like light off a puddle, quickly gone. “Anyway. Keys are useless to them. Locks are already open. They don’t come for things. They come for corners.”

“What are we supposed to do,” Mara asked, “if they take the corners? Our houses will roll away. All the tables will be round.”

He didn’t smile as much as he surrendered to the idea of smiling, and then the smile left him like a rumor leaves a room.

“Are you going to ask me why I have so many sticks?” he asked.

“No,” she said, which made him lift his eyebrows.

She had asked him two dozen times already; this was their game. And he had never answered in a straight line. Today, he said, “You carry a tool like a flag. You can either wave it or you can pretend it is a weather vane and hope the wind is patient with your pretense. People will come to you, Mara. People who say words like duty and humanity and curtain. People who whisper in their shirts. People who are sure. It’s a kind of hunger, certainty is. You should eat before they knock.”

“I already did,” she said, and then because he was right and because the infinate stabler had a way of making a day feel like a thing with edges, she ate again.

The knock came before the third day, because of course it did. You put a peculiar thing near a window and the city smells it. She had been rearranging the saucers into a pattern she was sure meant something—moon, moon, sea, egg, egg—and she left them half-made on the table and went to the door with the stabler in her pocket and her hair like she had been living.

The man on the stoop wore a uniform that was the opposite of the apes’: it made his edges softer. He had his papers in order and a smile like a physician or a salesman.

“Ms. Quill,” he said, “Mara, may I be ‘Mara’? It’s so much friendlier. I’m Corwin with the Council. You have something the city would like to borrow. Temporarily. For the good of—oh. Is that coffee?”

She did not move aside. “I’ll put the kettle on.”

“I do love a kettle,” he said, stepping in because people like him are made to step in. “My mother kept the kettle singing like a bird and the house was never—well. Do you mind if I set this folder here.”

He had the folder. Of course he had the folder. Inside were her notes, the careless ones, the ones she’d given to Laleh at the paper because Laleh had a laugh like a trap door and Mara liked to feed it. There were pictures of her fence with the raffia neatly stapled, and of the light in her left window like she forgot sometimes to turn it off. Her life rendered in reasonable arguments why she should cooperate.

“You have something,” he said again when the kettle had not boiled because he had lost track of his time and had forgotten who boiled what. “It’d be a kindness. Only for a few hours. The ring market—”

“Three days,” Mara said.

“Beg pardon?”

“They’ll go to the ring market in three days. That’s where you want my help. Bram says keys are safe. Corners aren’t.”

“Corners,” Corwin said, as if it were a code and as if he was translating it in his mouth. “We had a mathematician say something like that. She drew a square on the chalkboard and then erased all of it except one angle, and we all stood there like crows look at mirrors. We’ve been recommending circles where possible, but people like corners. We’re trying to change the fashion.”

Mara poured coffee and watched him be good at drinking it. He was a man who could pretend anything was pleasant, and sometimes that is more dangerous than delirium.

“What does the Council want me to do,” she asked, although her hand had already gone to the stabler in her pocket and found it too warm, like a small sleeping thing.

“You have a tool that might bind one thing to another. Strongly. Efficiently. If we can keep them from opening our corners, we can keep their columns outside. For a time. I know time is a small piece of bread and everyone wants a bite, but that’s what I’m offering you. A bite.”

“For what,” she said. “What are they after. Besides corners.”

Corwin touched the folder and said nothing for an elegant length of time. “Stability,” he said finally, which was not the same as saying corners. “You see, and please don’t repeat this to the man with the sticks, because he is allergic to words like mine, we suspect the raids are rehearsals. Not for war. For settlement. They don’t burn. They don’t—pardon—rape. They make measurements. They leave a thin wool on our lintels, sometimes, have you noticed, and our dogs sneeze for an hour. Our bakers say the bread comes out heavier the day after they pass. Our barbers say everybody comes in and wants their hair shorter like they are preparing to wear helmets. It’s a kind of survey. We think, if they think these houses are already theirs in some future we can almost see, they’ll be less likely to break them now. To keep the place tidy for themselves.”

“And the Council,” Mara said, “would prefer they feel the opposite.”

Corwin smiled, and the smile took all the easy out of his face. “I would prefer you to act as if you also live here. I hear you’re a very good neighbor.”

“You’ve been asking my neighbors about me,” she said, flat.

He folded his hands. “Bram says you are a busybody. This is not a bad word where I come from. My mother kept a list of births and deaths on the door and would go knock an hour after the knockers left with pies and envelopes and the names of good plumbers. We call that civic, where I come from. You have the tool, Ms. Quill. I’m here to make sure you get to use it for what it’s for.”

She wanted to ask: for what is it for? But the stabler thrummed in her pocket as if it could hear and as if it did not like being referred to in the general, like a woman being told she was a category. “Three days,” she said again, because it made the word feel round and she needed something round to hold.

They met where the clay arcades met the ring road. There were pots stacked in crescents and cinnamon knotted into sticks and a wind pulled long over the ground so the canvas tents flapped and the school kids ducked and came back up as if the day had winked. Mara wore a jacket with too many pockets. Bram carried a stick today, though he always had a stick; this one had a strip of cloth tied near the head, and if you squinted the cloth might have been a flag. Corwin had a pen in his shirt like a promise. The locksmith’s pretty son had his sleeves rolled up and grease on his knuckles and he winked for no reason at all except that he was young and the day seemed like a thing that could be placed in a pocket and brought out later, still warm.

The apes came as Corwin said they would not: they had no plan to be late and were. People hate their predictions to be wrong when they are official about it. Mara watched him swallow the error and make a different one with his second mouth. She felt the crowd collect around edges they couldn’t help making—corners at tent meets, corners at the base of a pillar where someone had left a broom, corners where two faces came together with a laugh and a hand tugged another hand into a shadow.

They came with their shields and their drums and the sound of bellows in a forge that someone had put under the earth. They came with tasseled blades that never cut and the self-same solemnity they wore in the laundries. They came. And then they stalled.

They stalled because Mara stepped forward, which was not the plan because there had never been a plan and she had told herself there should be one and then told herself the telling was a plan and had, in a small way, believed it. She put the infinate stabler like a carpenters’ truth out in front of her and opened the jaw and explained, with no words, that if anyone opened something today that shouldn’t be opened, they would close it. She felt the click no one else heard. She felt the crowd back up into a softer shape behind her, as if the street had become a set of lungs and someone had told it a joke.

The leader—leaders—came forward. Today there were two, or one and a mirror. The left one touched the ground with his spear and tapped out a pattern: tap, tap, nothing, tap. The right one hummed.

Mara said, “I’m Mara Quill,” which was not particularly useful, and then because she spoke fluent human she added, “If you touch our corners I will staple them back on.”

The left leader’s shoulders moved. It might have been laughter. It might have been breath. The right leader looked at her hand, not at her face, and then leaned his body—there were a lot of bodies. It’s easy to say “an ape” and imagine one thing. It’s better to say: a shoulder with a scar shaped like a piece of a moon, two knees that had grazed stone for reasons unknown, a wrist wrapped in red thread, a mouth that did not sit right because a tooth had grown in late and sideways. He leaned, and Mara saw it. It was quick, like a bird. A flick of tongue? No. A catch of light on a ring in the nose? Also no. It was his eye, and no one saw it, not even Bram who sees too much because he looked at something else right then (the hand of a child, maybe, because always he could find the child’s hand in the crowd)—and Mara saw the slit of the pupil and it was not a slit at all. It was a door. A rectangle that widened as the world brightened, a field’s view, a gate.

She laughed, not kindly. She couldn’t help it. It came out like a bark.

“You’ve been eating grass,” she said, and Corwin hissed and Bram said her name and the leaders heard something in her voice that we didn’t. They shifted. The one with the scar put his hand on his chest the way a man swears a thing. He did not speak words, or not in the way we make them. He bleated.

No one laughed but her and a baby and a dog.

Here is where stories fork. You tell the one where the village roars and the apes roar back and then there is a great rectifiable confusion. Or you tell the one where the woman with the odd tool blows it like a whistle and they all stop and take tea. Or you tell the one no one believes, where two truths show up at the same party in the same dress and you realize how little you know about the shape of a mouth or the meaning of a noise.

Bram stepped forward with his stick and put it down and then picked it up again, and that was some shepherd’s signal from an old, old country where the hills made their own weather and the sheep made their own bargains. The leaders turned their heads in the same way, like a flock does when a dog pivots, the same enclosed elegance. Their shoulders moved again. The right one bleated back, to test what language could do between humans and not-humans and something worse. The crowd’s patience stretched like warm candy. Corwin said “Now, now—,” and sound had never sounded less like meaning.

Mara lifted the stabler. “You think we don’t see you,” she said. She was shaking and she would not admit it even later. “Fine. Maybe we see you too much. Maybe we’ve been drawing the wrong pictures for the right myths. You like corners because corners keep the wind off. You like corners because corners keep you from being seen from all sides. You like corners because we live in them, because we are the sort of beasts that find a corner and claim it. But you’re not apes. You’re not, are you. Show me.”

She closed the jaw gently around the rim of the world and pressed. It was a trick she had learned with the peonies, when she’d been brave with flowers. You can bite a stem and hold up a drowned blossom and make it look like it is proud. You can press a hem and it won’t fray. You can, if you are patient, staple a lie to a lie and make a whole cloth.

The stabler sighed. The canvas tents stopped flapping though the wind still was. The dust froze mid-billow. The leader’s helmet did not fall because gravity did not need that kind of service from her; it tilted and the strap popped and there was wool where a throat should have been, thick and clean and smelling of lanolin and rain. It bristled. It had burrs, small ones, as if someone had walked through a story that had grown in a hedgerow.

There was no blood. There was no reveal like a melodrama. There was the thing that happens when your eyes decide they will stop lying to you right now, and all the tricks you taught to your mind—don’t look, don’t see, don’t think—get tired and sit down.

The crowd did not scream because it had never been taught how to make that sound. The apes—sheep, not apes—bleated, but it was not fear and it was not joy; it was a checking-in, like the sound people make at a table when a stranger sits down and takes off their hat and is not a stranger. The leader—the leaders—reached up and took the helmet entirely away.

“Good heavens,” Corwin said, and then covered his mouth because good heavens was a very funny thing to say at such a moment and he did not intend to be someone’s joke.

Bram’s stick drooped and then lifted. He looked not surprised, which told Mara he knew and also that he had not wanted to know in the way that counts.

“You’ve been walking them like men,” she said to him, not exactly kindly and not exactly unkind.

“We all have,” he said and did not make a poem of it.

The leader put a hoof on the spear, which was very much a stick now that you looked at it. The hoof was cloven. The straps that had held armor to wool looked like someone had practiced a lot of knots. Mara wanted to tidy them and did not. The leader’s eye—that gate—looked at her, and she looked back, and the stabler was heavy in her hand, as if it had eaten something rich.

He bleated. He bleated again, and the second time it was almost words, not hers, not Bram’s, not any that Laleh could print and feel right about, but something like obligation. It reminded her of the way Corwin had said duty, like it was a cake he liked but knew he should not have every day.

“Are you trying to tell me you came to save us,” Mara asked, and her voice wanted to be a whisper but it refused. “Because I am going to be a very difficult person about that.”

The leader looked down at the crack in the stone that wasn’t there anymore because she had fixed it with her foolishness and then back up at her. He bleated a little differently. He lowered his head, not to butt, but to show the crown of it, the way a sheep will when it acknowledges a dog, when it negotiates in that old mathematics.

Bram coughed his laugh. “They came to measure us. Herds measure, you know. That’s what they do. It’s not as martial as you love, Corwin. It’s not a war at all; that’s why they’ve been so bad at it.”

“Bad,” Mara said softly, not because she thought the sheep couldn’t hear and not because she thought it’d be gentle. “Bad at war and good at—what? Counting? Caring?”

“Keeping,” Bram said, and then shook his head because he spoke too much when the air got thin. “They’ll want to know if we’re going to wander. They’ll want fences without saying fences. They’ll want—”

“Stability,” Corwin said, as if he’d gotten it right after all, and maybe he had, and maybe his mother’s kettle had been singing this whole time and he had never heard the tune. “They want us in a pen. The city as a pen. The way that makes it sound worse than it is.”

Mara held the infinate stabler and looked at the sheep in armor and at the people pressed into shapes behind her and at Bram’s stick and Corwin’s pen and the locksmith’s pretty son scrubbing his knuckles like he could polish the day away to reveal something brighter. She did not speak for nine heartbeats. That’s a long time in a ring market when everyone has things to sell and everyone has things to buy and a rumor has a travel plan. It was long enough for her to find the edges of a thought and press them together and feel the sigh of a seam finding itself.

“All right,” she said, to the leaders who were not men and to the people who were and to herself, who had been both at times. “If you came to keep us, you have to do it by our terms. You have to let us keep the parts of us that leave. In return I’ll make you a bargain. You stop touching our corners, and I keep the ones we have. Not for you. For us. But you can—” she looked at Bram because sometimes you need someone to tell you if you’re talking sense or carving nonsense into the table with your knife—“you can… watch. From the hill. And you can tell us when the sky is wrong. And when wolves come, which they always do, you come, but you don’t take the lambs; you take the wolf. Do you see? Do you even see me.”

She did not know if the leader saw her. He bleated. He nodded. It looked like a nod. His wool shook because the wind remembered it existed and returned to do its work, and the canvas struck its ropes with the old interest of a drum seeking a song. Someone began to cry. Someone began to laugh. People do both when the world goes sideways and then insists that it was never upright in the first place.

Corwin exhaled. “You can’t make treaties,” he said, not unkind. “I mean, you can’t, you personally. I can’t explain the law. It requires …”

“Require me later,” Mara said. “Today I’m stapling.” She turned and put the infinate stabler, carefully, deliberately, on one of the market’s corners: post to rug, rug to road. The sigh when the jaw closed went through the crowd like a kiss pressed to a forehead. She moved to another corner and pressed again. People watched. They began to bring her corners. They offered the mistakes they had made with their tents and with their thresholds and with their lives. Men who had been angry an hour ago became helpful. A girl who had been bored became a champion of edges. When she stapled a fence in a way it had always wanted to be, the sheep leader bleated and another sheep bleated and the sound was not war and it was not an ending. It was maybe a beginning; she would not say it, but she felt the way the ground approved.

It is very hard to defend a city with a tool borrowed from an office. It is very hard to be the kind of person who knocks on everybody’s door and tells them their potted plant needs turning and then to be someone who lifts a device and says, I’m going to hold you together now, whether you agree or not, because the wind is playing tricks. It is hard, and Mara was not particularly good at it, not at first. But she was stubborn, and she catalogued, and she learned that a corner is the memory of a turn, which is why it hurts to see one battered. She learned where to press and where to hold off. She learned that some seams should be left open because a city needs to breathe like a boy.

By late, the apes-who-were-sheep had taken their helmets back and the dog that had laughed lay down in a stripe of light and fell asleep. Bram leaned his stick in the crook of his arm and said, “You know this isn’t over.”

“Nothing is over,” Mara said. “That’s the problem.”

He looked at her the way he looked sometimes, like he had known her far too long and not long enough. “I should have told you earlier,” he said. “I should have told you when you showed me that thing and it bit your thumb that day and you swore. I should have said: they’re sheep. You’d have laughed before the right time and then, today, you’d have cried before the wrong. But I thought if I didn’t say it out loud, it might not be true in the way that matters.”

“Is there a way that matters?” she asked.

He did not answer. Corwin did.

“Yes,” he said. “The way we write it down.”

“You’re not writing this one down,” Mara said, and there was enough tired in her voice to lay bricks.

Corwin smiled his second smile. “That’s what everybody says, the first time.”

She walked home with the infinate stabler long against her forearm like a sleeping cat. The street had changed. It had more corners than it had had that morning. Some were small, the kind you could tuck a secret in. Some were new and bright and looked like they would hurt if you ran into them too fast. She saw where she had missed a place and where someone had seen and patched it with string and hope. She saw Bram on his stoop and felt the ache of future nights when he wouldn’t be there and how the sticks would lean in the empty hallway as if they knew something about weather and absence. The sky had a wrong in it she could not name; it looked too close to the roofs or maybe the roofs had grown taller when nobody was watching.

When she went in, the saucers were still on the table in their almost-pattern, and she let them stay like that because they had their own opinion about arrangement. She put the stabler in the sink because it was the only place in her house that anything heavy sat and looked at all right and because it was where you put things you did not yet have words for. It made a sound when the porcelain kissed metal. It sounded like yes and like stop and like the last thing somebody says before the important thing they cannot say.

She did not sleep. She tried. The city turned in its bed. She listened to Bram’s cough and to the dogs and to the late step of a boy and to the quiet between three and four that belonged to no particular breed of creature. She thought about eyes like doors. She thought about the way the leader had dipped his head. She thought about Corwin, who was a man made of folders, and about Laleh, who had two pens in her hair and always wrote her name across a page before she wrote anything else on it, as if staking it. She thought about all the corners she had tightened today and the ones that would spring when the day warmed, because that was the way of things, that they tried to become themselves when you held them, and some of them succeeded.

When morning took its breath, she got up and went to the market before anyone else. She walked the perimeter. The sheep had left a strand of wool on one of the posts, and she lifted it and twisted it the way she had once twisted a curl when a girl and liked herself. It smelled like weather. She put it in her pocket.

At the cracked stone she had fixed—which was not cracked anymore because she had made it not crack but which remembered itself anyway when you stepped just right—she paused, as the apes had done, and thumped it with her knuckle. It made the noise a pot makes when it expects soup soon. She decided she would make soup.

On the second day after she had pulled a helmet off a sheep and said aloud something no one wanted to put their mouths around, Corwin came back, and Laleh came to make the story behave, and Bram did not come because he was watching a sky on a hill and listening to a gap in the wind you only heard if you’d been taught by lambs. The Council would want to enlist her. People would bring her things to fix, beyond corners, to make them stay or not—wounds, promises, a marriage, a road. There were wolves, after all. There are always wolves. And there were sheep who were not what they wore, and people who had never been anything other than what they claimed, and a tool in a sink that could fasten a day to a day and make it hold.

She did not want to be the kind of person who walked into rooms and made lines with her hands. She had wanted small things: to have a cup ready when someone came in, to know when the rain would stall, to know who in the building was happy and who was not. She had wanted, at most, to be the woman with saucers who knows where all the saucers in a building are. And yet the world had called on her to staple it, to keep it together, to hold on. Someone had to. The city was too proud to ask, but it had asked anyway when it let the apes enter and didn’t bar the gates with anything but custom and convenience.

“It was always you,” Bram had told her once, when he’d had just enough to drink to allow himself an unlovely truth. He had said it like he was telling her where her lost glove had gone. She had pretended not to hear. She heard now, in the wake of bleats and sighs and helmet straps. It tasted like pennies. It tasted better as it sat.

When Laleh came she looked at the stabler and made her face neutral and wrote down the thing without writing it down at all. “So,” she said, “the apes are sheep.”

“It turns,” Mara said, “that everything is a sentence you are still reading, and this is the clause where we turn the page.” She hated herself a little for the drama. Laleh wrote it down anyway and added an exclamation point in her head and then crossed it out in the same head because she was disciplined.

Corwin brought the folder. He put it on the table like a gift he was uncertain was appropriate. “I need you to understand,” he said. “Once we say it, once we write it, it’s true in the way that matters. People will make habits out of it. They’ll bring them flower crowns. They’ll break their shields for combs. They’ll forget the part where wolves have teeth. They’ll forget the part where sheep have teeth, too.”

Mara picked up the wool from her pocket and pulled it to a longer thread until it snapped. She felt the energy in the break. She thought of the way the stabler sighed. She thought of how the leaders’ pupils had opened like doors and the way the city had not decided yet whether to be flattered or afraid.

“I’m not going to protect us from a truth,” she said softly. “I might try to staple it down so it doesn’t blow away.”

Corwin sat. Laleh stood. Somewhere, Bram whistled and a line of creatures changed direction.

Mara placed the strand of wool on the table and made two ends meet. She lifted the infinate stabler and pressed its jaw open and set it around the meeting place with a familiar care. She hesitated and then she pressed.

The sigh made the saucers hum. The seam held. The air steadied. The day decided to be a day again. And in the hills, in a place where no one had told anyone what to call it, a flock lifted its heads and then went on chewing.By afternoon the newspaper had found a way to say what it could not say without looking foolish, which is the great work of newspapers. Laleh’s headline did not announce anything so much as blink at the reader and dare them to finish the sentence for themselves: Helmets and Wool: What We Learned at the Ring last Marketday. The picture showed a line of shields and a canvas tent behaving and the corner of a hoof as if a horse had wandered into frame, which of course none had. The piece named no names but everybody wrote the names in anyway: that’s Mara Quill, that’s Bram with one of his batons, that’s Corwin frowning like he is trying not to frown. Neighbors stopped in the bakery to pinch the paper between fingers still sugar-dusted and permit themselves opinions that had been waiting all their lives for a subject. “They were always sheep,” one said with authority not available until this instant, and, “Nonsense, I have seen an ape’s hand in my dreams,” said another, and between those two statements the city made itself busy the way people arrange chairs at a kitchen table to make a hard conversation friendlier, and just as likely to curdle into something louder.

Mara had not intended to read it, but of course she did, re-folding the page after as if nothing had been unfolded, like an apology made to a napkin. She stood at the sink and let the sink run and then remembered she had a gift for missing what was right in front of her. The infinate stabler sat at the bottom of the basin like a fish that had decided to be still in a shallow pool. The water threaded itself around it and did not rise. It should have. It did not. The tap ran sound and air, a thin hiss that made her teeth think of wool. She shut it off and touched the stabler with two fingers as if feeling for a pulse on a throat. It was warm without being hot and dry without being dry in the normal way; it was the dryness of a page that has been licked by a person who thinks this will make the pen behave better.

People began coming without asking permission, which meant they knocked first and then knocked again while their faces were already inside, a choreography she had trained herself to enjoy and secretly despise. A woman from the fifth floor with the baby that had laughed at the market came with a basket that contained no baby, only bills and envelopes and a braid of garlic as if vampires had been invited and were late. “Can you fasten this,” she asked, and Mara knew she did not mean the garlic, which had its own talent for binding scents to days. “He says he’ll stop spending on marmalade we don’t like. He says it’s a small thing and that’s the smallness of it that makes it sweet. He says a lot of things. Could you make one of them true.”

Mara motioned to the table, to the pattern of saucers she had finally surrendered to, and the woman sat and put the basket down as if fiction were being made. “It doesn’t work like that,” Mara said. “It barely works at all. It works on seams that already know they are seams. It doesn’t make a seam where no seam belongs. It does not—” she looked at the garlic, which had its own opinions—“it does not trick husbands into sense.”

The woman made a noise like she knew that and had hoped to forget it long enough to have someone else tell her. She left the bills and the garlic anyway because being seen leaving something behind in Mara’s kitchen was a kind of act that could be referred to later and comfort the right set of nerves at three in the morning. After, a boy came with a kite that needed to be more sky than string and a teacher came with a stack of essays that needed to be more argument than display and a man came with a watch that had lost its afternoons. Mara did what she could for the kite and told the teacher that she could only staple ideas if the girls writing them wanted to be held to their words—not all of them did, some were practicing how to slip—and for the man she had nothing but a cup of coffee and two kinds of silence. She felt wicked saying no. The city had appointed her—it had not; it had only glanced at her with the particular light that means now, now—and she had said yes to everything that could be made into a list. She reminded herself that staples are not prayers. They are just a way of asking two edges to be courteous.

Corwin arrived with his suit like a weather system, bringing the smell of ink and shoe polish and that sweet blue thread all paperwork carries even when the papers are blank. He put the folder on her table and took his time because men like him live longer in the space they occupy when they are inconveniencing someone they imagine they can persuade. He did not look at the saucers. He had trained himself not to look at a person’s small peculiarities the way you train a dog not to stare at the meat you are saving for later. “We opened a conversation,” he said, making “we” do the work of “I did not get shouted at for this and would like to continue not getting shouted at,” and Mara poured water for him and made a face for him to ignore.

“There are wolves,” he said, only after biscuits and the kind of talk that passes for immediate between people who pretended yesterday did not happen. “Bram is gone; he left me a note that smelled like grass and told me he would be where grass listens. The shepherds—they have shepherds in the hills, did you know, not just men like Bram who stand alone with their sticks in a city street and scare children into better posture—they sent word that path-wolves have been seen on the iron seam.”

Mara didn’t know about path-wolves because no one had told her, which was astonishing because she was certain she had been told everything worth knowing since the day she learned to go down stairs with her cup and not spill a drop. “Path-wolves,” she said, tasting it. “Like wolves, but with paths,” she said, because her brain did better when it could goad her mouth into helping, and Corwin made a rectangle in the air with his fingers and tapped the corners, an unconscious little prayer he did now without knowing it.

“Like wolves who do not need mouths,” he said. “Like wolves that choose the easy way down a hill and then choose it again and then make the earth decide for itself that this is the way always, and then everything that walks must walk in that groove or risk falling. They dig with time, Mara. They make paths that are ruts and then roads and then habits. We had them once, anyone with a grandmother will tell you. They took the alley behind a house until the alley was the only way to the house, and then the house was the alley. We paved them out, or we thought we did, but the quarries have been busy, and the seam is exposed, and the wolves have teeth like repetition.”

She thought of the apes-that-weren’t, their rectangular eyes, their love of corners not for owning but for managing, for taking attendance. She thought of Bram with a stick on a hill whistling at a sky. She thought of her tool, which did not make wolves or cure them, but might stop a corner from forgetting itself in the face of a groove’s nagging. “You want me to—what. Staple roads to their place,” she said. “Staple habits to a set of manners. Staple path to path so it cannot widen into a will.”

He gestured with his pen and almost laughed. “I want you to come see. At least come see. You and Bram love to see. You can leave the tool at home if you think it will sulk in company.”

The seam ran raw as a vein from the quarry all the way down to where the sea ate any promise you gave it out of courtesy. It sparkled where the sun found it, a glitter that made children point and then stop pointing because you tell your hands not to be rude in public and sometimes they listen. The first time she walked along it as a girl—there had been a picnic, and a different man called dear then, and her saucers had an actual service to be part of—she slid one foot along the iron to feel the world hum and was scolded into hand-holding and caution. Now, with Corwin and his pen and a woman from Public Safety who had the posture of someone who had slept in her clothes and liked it, Mara stood and saw how the path-wolves had begun their work. You cannot see a wolf until it has decided to show itself, but you can see where it is going to be later. There were lines in the dirt where there should have been scatter. There were lines in the grass where there should have been scuffle. The seam had a run, like a stocking. It was beautiful if you decided having your choices narrowed was beautiful.

Bram stood a little way up and lifted his stick, not as greeting but as proof that he had brought to the hill the one thing on earth that confessed honestly to being a tool. He was not alone. The shepherds were nothing like their stories; the stories made them humble and taciturn and dusty and carrying lambs over their shoulders without complaint. The people on the hill were chatty and well-shod and had knives for cutting bread that had never seen a sheep’s wool in their lives. They had dogs whose eyes were triangles of intent and whose bodies were made entirely of the knowledge that they were right when they moved left. They kept their hats tight, because wind. They had wrists wrapped in red threads and scars in parallel lines that made Mara’s hands feel like paper.

“Path-wolves,” one said, not to Corwin but to the woman from Public Safety because he had recognized her as a person who knew how to have a plan and had perhaps never met one of those in the hills. “They like a seam. They like it because it is already a decision. All they have to do is make the decision tire itself out so we accept it. You get one cart wheel after another and before you can say, who tied this knot, you have a groove that knows your grandmother’s name.”

“We could pave,” the woman said, staring, because it is the first response of an urban mind when a wild thing begins to make art.

“We could pave,” Bram said, from his place, “and that would be a path-wolf’s favorite. Paving is a kind of worship for them. It is the final confession. ‘We will always be this way here,’ the street says. Then it can sit and wait for hooves.”

Mara crouched and pressed her fingers along the iron seam, finding where the earth gave and where it resisted with personality. The stabler in her bag shifted, an animal waking. She had promised herself she would leave it home and had not fulfilled that promise; people do that when they are very sure of themselves. “We could stitch,” she said without meaning to speak out loud. Bram heard her across too much air because that’s what being alive with a person looks like, sometimes; they hear your mouth before your mouth hears it. He glanced down.

“You could stitch,” he said. “You could make the corner a place that resists forgetting. You could make it say ‘I am a turn’ and not ‘I am an invitation to a straight line.’ Does your tool like that.”

Mara put the bag down and took the thing out and held it in a way that made the shepherds stop looking at her face and start looking at the mouth of metal the way you look at a dog’s mouth, calculating for kindness. There are ways to show strangers that you mean well without teaching them your whole biography. She pressed her hand along the jaw the way she had pressed it along the iron and listened to the almost-sigh it gave before the sigh it would have given. “It likes being asked,” she said. “It does not like being told. It refuses the work if I speak to it as if I had purchased it. The man who gave it to me coughed the way secrets cough and did not tell me where it came from but the word he wrote looked like ‘stabler,’ not because of staples but because of stables, I think. I think someone meant for it to keep things.”

“Stabler,” Bram said, and his mouth tasted the word like salt. “Yes. The old word in the hills for a person who keeps sheep at night is not ‘shepherd,’ it is ‘night-stabler.’ Not a stable at all, of course, but the person who makes the flock decide to behave like a flock when the dark has other ideas. You put the nights together until the dawn can handle it.”

Corwin wrote that down without meaning to, as if the pen had its own flocking instinct. The Public Safety woman took a step closer to the seam. “Pave and stitch and fence,” she said, trialing the words like she could hold one in her hand and discover its temperature. “I can budget for fence. The city likes a fence so much it tends to forget what it is for. People will paint it and call it their friend. Will you show me what stitching looks like before we spend money we will be ashamed we spent.”

The seam had a place where it kinked up as if a knee had pushed under it in a dream. Mara set the jaws there and did not close them. She waited the way you wait a kettle, pretending not to stand over it. The tool softened her palm with its warmth. She remembered stapling the peony to its stick and the way it had sagged because some things prefer bowing to being righted. “This is a bad idea,” she said to Bram, to test what an echo would do.

“It’ll be worse when it works,” he said, very gently.

She closed the jaw. The sigh went out and came back to her like wind through a window you have cleaned too well, and the seam did not lie down so much as remember lying down was possible. The iron didn’t melt; it never does what you ask when you are theatrical. The earth around it bound itself to the idea of itself at that spot. Grass that had been thinking about a career in line-making decided, for today, to be patches and not a path. A dog lay down and stretched and let its paws be paws and not direction. Mara pulled back and breathed for herself and not the city.

The shepherds made a noise like approval that had been taught not to trust itself. Corwin exhaled in relief in the way a man does when he has successfully placed someone in the correct chapter in his binder. The woman from Public Safety was already calculating how many lengths of fence made sense if you were going to keep wolves from pretending to be roads. Bram leaned on his stick and looked away because when something is good you sometimes have to practice not looking for a moment so you will be better at looking later.

Mara sat on the grass because knees. The world had a tilt to it when she lowered, like a plate on a table someone had kicked. The tool in her hand had its weight and its appetite and she felt, as she always did after she let it kiss the edges of a thing, that somewhere a seam had closed that should not have and she would be embarrassed by that later when she found it. She made a list in her head of the corners that needed auditing by afternoon. She wished she could staple time to something and then immediately knew better than to wish out loud.

They put up a fence where the seam met the easy road, not a prison fence, though of course a fence is always a cousin to a prison; they strung it with bells the shepherds brought that had belonged to nobody and everyone. The bells were not loud. They were the sort of bells you hear only when you are already thinking about bells. That kind are the most useful; they remind the world of itself. Mara touched them and they quieted. Her tool did not like metal on metal. It sulked. She petted it. Bram watched as if someone had placed his heart on the ground and then stacked walnuts around it very carefully.

On the way down the hill she found him walking beside and slightly behind her the way someone does who wants to be in your company and not your conversation, and then because he is not a fool he made himself a fool and said the thing no one knew how to say without ruining a day. “You stapled a cough,” he said, so mildly that the needles of the words found her late.

“I know,” she said. “I was sorry as soon as I did it. He wrote me and said his chest stopped troubling him and then he didn’t know how to clear his throat when he was alone and someone spoke at the door and he hadn’t had a chance to think yet. He said he sat there with his mouth open like a fish when the man with the pamphlets came and he could not conjure the cough and so he had to listen.”

“It’s too good a tool for a person,” Bram said, as if he could tuck the pronouncement into a pocket and hope never to have to take it out. “It makes invitations.”

Later, after fence and bells and a blunt conversation with Corwin about forms, the Council called a meeting in the clay arcades. Laleh sat on a pottery wheel like a queen of things that spin and a girl filled a jug with questions and then poured them on the floor in a shape that looked like ambition. The locksmith’s pretty son leaned in a corner he had not asked permission to lean against and smiled at things that did not exist. The city attended the way the city attends when it smells a change: it bought cinnamon in lengths and argued about umbrellas and left early and came back to complain that it had missed the important part.

The sheep came. Not as a column. As themselves, which meant as a decision distributed over many animals and held together by notes. You could hear the bleats and tell that some were boredom and some worry and some hunger and some the sound a creature makes when the hoof is clean and the field is quiet and there is work and no sword. Helmets under arms, they walked without marching and stood without arranging themselves into meaning you could get from above. They watched the corners like scholars of geometry looking at somebody else’s theorem. The leader had the wrong tooth and the scar that looked like the piece of a moon. He dipped his head. It was not submission. It was politeness.

Corwin stood on a crate because he wanted very much to be taller just for today, just until the pen he held felt as useful as he hoped. “We propose a charter,” he said, in a voice he had practiced that morning in a mirror and in the kettle. “Not a treaty, because a treaty presumes we could both be somewhere else if we liked. A charter presumes we are where we are because we care to be and because we intend to carry on being here under certain conditions. Conditions include: you don’t take our corners; we don’t pretend your eyes are circles. You warn us about wolves, the path kind, the tooth kind, the people kind. We warn you about our unpredictable habits, which are legion and were raised without oversight. We will accept bells. We will not accept pens in our bedrooms.”

The leader listened, which looked like chewing. Bram stood alongside and said nothing because sometimes the right amount of shepherd in the room is exactly one, and he had decided he had already been that today. Laleh wrote. The crowd made a noise that could go either way and pinned it to the air like a piece of laundry so that they could point later and say, we said something.

Mara watched the leader’s eyes go door-wide when a cloud moved. She watched the way the sheep did not like the sound the pottery wheel made when its belt slipped and the potter swore softly, fashioning the air back into his own. She held the stabler down by her side and hoped no one would ask her to hold up her hand and swear. She did not want to. She wanted to staple the idea of a charter to the day and then take her pockets for a walk. She wanted Bram to say something gnomic and wrong that made her think for an hour. She wanted Corwin to be less careful. She wanted the boy with the kite to find the right wind and let it out like a sentence that knows it is going to be read aloud.

When the charter had been spoken and the bleats had the sound of consent—not exactly consent, something like “we are amenable”—when the bells had been distributed behind hands into a dozen apron pockets, people began to treat the sheep as sheep. This is to say: they tried to feed them. A child with a fistful of mint held it up and was nearly tipped over by a polite mouth. A baker brought the ends of bread like an apology to Scythes and offered them as if bread can solve allegory. Three men went off to get combs. A girl plaited red into her own hair in copy of a wrist she had seen and decided that would make her see like a sheep, which is the kind of magic the city understands. Corwin was given a bell and he jangled it exactly once and looked terrified by the thinness of the sound and did not do it again.

Mara excused herself before she could be asked to fix anybody’s promise, and went to look for a crack. Not because she wanted to close it; because she wanted to be made to leave something alone. She found one where two stones met and had never quite forgiven each other for being near. She put her finger along it and felt how the day had slipped down into its little canyon and slept there quietly. She did not open the jaw. She did not sigh for it. She only hummed, low, a song she did not remember learning, a thing with no words that knew how to follow a line and not turn it into a path. The crack ignored her, which was its right. She felt better.

The wolves did not wait for the charter to be argued through the Council’s appetite. They arrived that night under the sort of wrong that looks like wind. Bram had given her words for them: path-wolves of habit, of repetition, of the way the ground prefers to remember footsteps rather than make new prints. Corwin had given her words too: deliverables, metrics, engagement. None of those words helped when the first of them slipped along the iron seam and pressed its suggestion into the dirt near the fence and the bells refused to ring because the wrong was so polite. It was the hour when people think they are quietly being themselves and in truth they are most available to becoming someone else. The sheep heard them first. The sound they made brought the city to windows and then to shoes and then to the fence with cups still in their hands because all emergencies are improved by the presence of dishes.

They were not wolves the way a child draws wolves, with teeth like the crowns of hills and breath that makes frost jealous. They were long and low and did not quite touch the ground; they were smudges with decisions, precise where a foot should go and indefinite where a tail might be. They were made of every time you went the same way home because why not, you know it, it knows you, why test yourself. They pressed against the fence not with strength but with patience. They made the fence think about its favorite places to lean. The bells said nothing. The sheep bleated in a tone Mara had not heard and could not inventory. It was not fear, not in a way she had a label for. It was a sound like the number five.

Bram stepped into the groove a wolf had made and whistled a note Mara wanted to put on a shelf and dust. The wolf hesitated, the way a thought will when you interrupt it with laughter. Corwin came with his pen and the woman from Public Safety came with nine men and six women and a roll of chalk. They began to draw circles around the places where the ground had decided to become somebody’s habit. Chalk is a kind of magic even grown-ups will keep in the kitchen. Laleh arrived with a notebook and did not write down anything except the way the sheep had lined themselves along the fence in such a way that if you were a wolf made of persistence you would feel the exact pressure of being watched.

Mara held the stabler and put its mouth to the fence where two wires touched and meant to keep meaning to. She pressed and felt the sigh go sideways, into the attention of the wolves, which is to say into the places where they were not yet wolves but could be if they were encouraged. She had not known she could do that. She set the tool at the seam and found the exact notch where the iron loved itself most, if iron can be said to indulge. She stapled that to the day, she stapled that to the fence, she stapled that to the way children turned their heads when their mothers said their names. She did not do it more than three times because Bram had told her once that three is the polite number when a person is listening and you do not know yet if they want to be persuaded.

The wolves pressed and in pressing revealed their edges, because everything that persists has to show you where it begins and ends eventually or else it never existed. She saw the noses, if noses are the first place a decision comes out of the dark. She saw the shoulders, if shoulders are the parts of a thought that move the rest. She saw the permanent mark they wished to make. She pressed again and fastened the moment to itself. One of the wolves stepped into a circle the woman had chalked and hesitated because chalk is old. It remembers when we used to write on the ground to ask the sky to take us seriously. It did not cross the line. It moved along the circumference and tried to become the circle’s twin and tired and stopped and looked at its friends the way you do when you’ve gotten lost and think you can pretend that was your plan.

The bells at last chose to admit that they had roles. They rang. It was not loud. None of this ever was. It was quiet enough to make you hate yourself for making too much noise with your thoughts. The sheep looked at Mara in a way that felt like someone had folded a page of a book you were trying to keep clean, and dipped their heads, and then did something complicated with their bodies that made the pressure change. It was a flock thing. You move here and you move here and you let there be a hole there and a wall there and suddenly the choice the wolf wanted is no longer inevitable. The path the wolf loved most had a hill in it of a sort that did not exist before and now did.

After a long hour the wolves left. They left the way you stop thinking about a bad decision that wants to become a habit: you tell yourself a story about something else. They will come back. They are wolves. That is what wolves are for. The bells kept ringing after because bells take their time the way grief does. People went home with cups, finally empty, and shoes, finally noticed. Bram sat on the ground and folded his stick along his thighs and sighed in a way that was not at all like a seam finding itself; it was a way a person exhales when they have postponed despair without cancelling it.

Corwin put a hand on the fence not to claim it and not to bless it but to discover if the fence was the sort of object that could be grateful. He found it could, a little, and smiled and looked more tired than she had ever allowed him to look. Laleh closed her notebook without writing the paragraph that would tell the city that wolves have good manners and bad ideas and that all of them are easier to manage than men.

Mara went home with the tool under her arm, which was asleep in the way tools sleep, which is to say ready. She thought of the man who had coughed and pressed pencil into paper to tell her a word she did not properly understand. She thought of the saucers on her table and the way they had organized themselves in her absence into a pattern that meant nothing and everything, as patterns do. She thought of the crack she had found and not mended and felt the pride of restraint and the itch of neglect. She fed the plant in the sink, which had been deprived of its water earlier by a tool with its own notions. It drank and forgave. Plants are good at that.

At the door she found a note under the mat because people still do that when they want you to find a thing with your foot before your eye. It smelled of pencil and wool and a kitchen with bread cooling. It said, in Bram’s writing, which always made you think his pen had a limp: We need to go to the quarry tomorrow. Bring the thing. Don’t tell Corwin until we are there. He will pretend he thought of it. There are sheep up high that do not come down and a sound that is not a wolf and not a bell and not the rain in the mouth of the pipe. We should listen to whatever it is saying to the iron. Also I have more coffee if you bring a saucer.

She read it twice and then put it against the cold of the window and watched it fog the tiny bit a note can fog. The city turned itself into shapes around her like a cat looking for the right shape to sleep in. She closed the curtains and let the day unhook from its corners. The tool in the sink did not look like anything you could write a rule about. It looked like a thing that would one day be a story someone else told, with your name in it if you were unlucky, with your face softened by time and other people’s memory. She went to bed and lay on her side with one hand on her stomach and one on the blankets and thought about fences and wolves and the way you can staple a seam and still be kind.

In the morning the market smelled like cinnamon and rain. Children had chalk on their knees. A man had painted a bell on his door and then rang it until his wife said she liked the real one better. The sheep had left a pattern in the dust that Mara wanted to write down and then decided if she wrote down their pattern it would become easier to predict and she would be tempted to use that prediction like a hammer. She folded her coat the way Bram folded his stick and put the stabler in the pocket you put things in when you want them close enough to deny they are heavy. She brought a saucer that was cracked handsomely, because we should always put our best cracked things in circulation when we can.

Bram was at the foot of the quarry road, looking like a man who had already climbed it and decided to go again for the luxury of complaining. He had the air of someone who had been in company with a sound all night. “The sheep up there,” he said, without hello because it was a morning when hello would have been a delay, “they stand on ledges and put their ears to stone and hum. I have never seen them do that. I think the iron is speaking to them. I think the seam is telling them a story about itself from before it was a seam. I would like to know if what they are hearing is a warning or a comfort. Bring your tool but do not put it on the iron unless it asks.”

“What does asking look like,” Mara said, already her feet making decisions about where to find purchase on a slope that had forgiven too many people already.

“It looks like every part of you being quiet at the same time,” Bram said, which was not useful and always was.

The quarry opened around them like a mouth with its tongue torn out. There were ledges and scars and the smell of a world being made convenient for other worlds. The sheep stood like statues at intervals and put their heads sideways as if collecting rain in a cup made of ear. When they hummed, the air thickened the way a room does when someone you have loved finally says the thing they have been promising to say and you have no idea if it is what you wanted to hear. The hum had age in it. It had the grit of timelines. It had the shape of a road that had not yet decided which village deserved it.

Mara held the stabler and did not use it. Bram closed his eyes and looked like a man discovering an old prayer pinned under a new one. The sheep lifted their heads together and bleated once, a sound that sounded less like bleeding and more like the hinge of a gate being honest about needing oil. The iron sang back. It was not a wolf and not a bell and not the rain in the mouth of a pipe. It was a seam telling a story: I was the riverbed you forgot. I was the length of a dragon’s sleep. I was where men in armor counted their steps and learned to stack metal on metal and call it safety.

Corwin appeared at the top of the path because a man like that cannot be left out of a paragraph even if you try, carrying himself like someone who has already written down what is going to happen and will be embarrassed at how wrong he is but will recover. He opened his mouth to ask for permission to be in the presence of a thing he would eventually regulate. The sheep looked at him kindly and went on listening. Bram put his finger along the iron as if taking a pulse. Mara felt the tool shiver, not with fear, which it did not believe in, but with recognition. The iron did not ask, not yet. She let her fingers curl around the handle and waited to be quiet. She made a list of all the corners she would not touch today. She put her name at the bottom of the list, which felt like the right order.

Below them, along the seam, the chalk circles had caught a new shape. Not a wolf. Not a man. Not a sheep. A sort of loose, like a plan that had not been agreed upon but was walking around anyway seeing if anyone would mistake it for official. It moved toward the city and the bell fence the way a thought moves toward a sentence. Bram inhaled. The sheep stepped backward without any one of them deciding to. Corwin lifted his pen because you reach for who you are when you are afraid. The iron lifted its story by one octave and something under the earth cleared its throat. The stabler warmed in Mara’s hand like a cat vowing nothing and promising everything.The iron sang again, and this time the note lengthened until it felt like a rope thrown between two boats. Mara felt it tug at her wrists and become the kind of question you didn’t answer with words so much as with posture. Bram’s eyes had gone narrow, not from suspicion but from care, like a man sighting the line between two long grasses to see what runs there, and the Public Safety woman had her chalk poised above the ground, waiting for the moment when a circle is a ceremony and not just a shape. Corwin’s pen had found his breast pocket and stayed there as if relieved; this was no place for ink. The loose shape below—an intention without a skin—tested the chalk rim again and strolled along it, shoulderless and sure until it faltered at a corner and went dim because corners are interruptions, and interruptions are the only things that have ever saved a city. The sheep on the ledges hummed in thirds and then in a low ribbon of fifths, and Mara felt the weak places in the seam flinch as if embarrassed to be caught slouching. The tool in her hand leaned toward the iron the way a moth leans toward a porch light and stopped just before singeing because some lessons you only have to learn once.

She had been told to wait until the iron asked, and in the din of hum and thought and the audible stamina of stone, she heard it. It was not a word. It was a thinning, the sound a thread makes when a little boy pulls it through a hole in his sweater and the sweater considers becoming something else. It was not urgent. It was patient, which was worse. Mara lifted the stabler and balanced its open jaw just above a seam-shoulder that had tried too often to be a road and failed and then decided to make the failure permanent. She did not close it. She looked at Bram, whose stick rested against his leg like a tame river, and he nodded once, not as license but as witness. A sheep with a burr in its flank turned its rectangular eye upon her and dipped its head, and that was all she was going to get from the wool.

“If you behave,” she said quietly to the tool, which was the only way she could behave herself, “I will find you something beautiful later to fasten that has no consequence. I will staple a ribbon to a child’s hair and you may preen.” The stabler warmed the way a face warms when you compliment the wrong thing but mean it kindly, and she closed the jaw on iron and air and wool together because there was a tuft caught on the stone and she would have been foolish not to include it in the bargain. The sigh moved through the ledges and through the chalk, which lifted in a draught and then settled into itself like a cat resettling in its own fur. The loose shape below stumbled over the suddenly well-behaved notch the seam made and broke into three smaller notions, each less convinced of its own inevitability than the last.

Corwin exhaled as if he had been holding his breath since the sea was invented. The Public Safety woman squinted down the slope and then up at Mara as if to say: I have a warehouse of rope and barrels of nails and none of them do what you just did, which is both infuriating and a relief. Bram did not move. The sheep moved in a way that made the ledges look briefly like grammar and then like melody again, and one of them bleated a sound that had the comfort of a closing door without the insult of being shut out. The iron’s story softened back down to where it could be ignored by a man buying a pie and cherished by a dog that knew the difference between weather and news.

“Do not do it again here,” Bram said, friendly as a fencepost. “You’ve set the staple deep because you included what the seam thinks of itself. That means if you fix another length too close you’ll make them call to each other and then we will have a wall where a seam belongs. People do not like walls unless they can paint them, and I do not wish to explain to the Council why we are suddenly a castle.”

“I have no interest in castles,” Mara said, and it was true until the moment the word made a structure in the air and she realized: a castle is only corners with better publicity. The stabler settled against her palm and breathed. It did that, sometimes, when it had eaten well. She wanted very much to laugh and did not, because of Corwin’s face, which had the look of a man who had just watched someone fix his job by accident. The Public Safety woman spoke first because that was her craft. “We will run rope down from the ledge,” she said, pointing, “and hang bells where the iron flinches. Your chalk circles can be made official. I can get the city to sign a paper that says we respect the difference between a road and a rut. It will make no difference to the wolves, but it will make a difference to men.”

The loose shape down on the flat did not dissolve so much as lose credibility. A plan undone. It slid toward the sea like an idea hoping salt would fix it, which never works and always looks elegant. The sheep watched it leave with the mild disdain of a creature that has survived a thousand versions of a thing and knows all their endings, and then they turned back toward their ledges and put their ears to stone again as if the seam had gone back to telling them a story worth being quiet for. Corwin put his hand on the iron the way a boy in church pats a carved saint when no one is looking. He nodded, small, as if the iron had told him something he had understood and promised not to repeat. He was not the sort of man who would keep that promise, but he was at least the sort who would be embarrassed when he broke it.

On the climb down, when the air stopped buzzing and the earth resumed its old habit of pretending it never speaks, Bram shouldered his stick and let a breath out as if someone had called his name from very far away and then decided it was a different Bram they wanted. “Night-stabler,” he said, not fussing over the word as if proud to be holding something old enough to splinter. “There was a woman once, up in Prent’s Fold, who bound storms. Not to the fence—don’t look at me like that, I can tell that’s where your head goes. She tied them to themselves. Gave the thunder back to the clouds and the clouds back to the thunder and told the hill to sit down and not take anything personally. It worked, until it didn’t. She did a fourth, after three, because somebody she liked was coming over the saddle and did not deserve to drown. She kept the storm for him and after that all our weather was tired for a year. Grain sulked. Children were listless. Even the dogs dreamed of shade. The hill forgave her, eventually, but it named a gully for her in a way that makes the gully a warning if you know your maps.”

“I like three,” Mara said, to make her mouth believe it. “I liked three in school, when teachers made us speak to be certain we had learned. Once to say it. Once to demonstrate it. Once to be sure we would remember the shape of the saying. Four is show-off business. Four is thinking you are the outside of your own life.” She gripped the tool until it ceased thinking about jumping.

Corwin caught up, wearing the look of someone about to make himself useful so that he could forgive himself later for having been frightened. “We will need to draft guidance,” he said, and Bram barked a laugh so abrupt the sheep on the ledge above them turned their heads as one. “No, listen,” Corwin went on, a man pleading with laughter to be kind. “If we are to tell people not to overfasten their corners, we have to define corner. If we are to tell them wolves can be undone by chalk and singing and that woman’s impossible device, we have to distribute chalk and bells and some species of patience. We have to tell people that they themselves are the best part of the fence and the worst, depending on the hour they wake.”

“Put all of that on a poster,” Mara said, and surprised herself by meaning no harm. “Add a picture of a lamb for the children to color. Add a corner—no, two—and a line in the middle one must not cross. Try to avoid words like mandate, which make people yawn and then rebel. Perhaps staple one to every door.” She knew she had said the word on purpose and did not apologize for it. He deserved to have his verbs stolen now and then.

They met the shepherds where the path widened into conversation. A woman with hair like old straw made new smiled at the stabler the way you smile at a very large sweet dog that hasn’t chosen a target yet. “Stabler?” she asked, and Mara nodded. “Good,” the woman said. “The iron will talk faster now it has found an ear that knows when to close.” She held out a hand. “Tamsin. I keep the bells from turning vain and the dogs from falling in love with their own work. If you need wool that has not yet learned bad habits, you ask me. If you need wool that has learned every habit and can teach you which ones are useful, you ask Calder, who has been old since birth and hasn’t noticed. We will make a calling cry you can hear in your kitchen when we need you. It will sound like the kettle behaving wrong. You will be disgusted by it and you will be quick.”

Mara felt her ribs grow a size and make room for a new kind of hurry. “If the iron asks and I am peeling potatoes,” she said, and left it there because that was a better prayer than anything with saints in it. Tamsin nodded as if Mara had passed some exam that had never been written down. Bram, looking relieved to let someone else stand in front, turned to Corwin and said, “Write your charter, binder-man, but add a clause that says we are permitted to not be the sort of people who need charters on Wednesdays. The hill doesn’t understand Wednesdays but it does like kindness. If you teach the city to do that, we might forgive it its squares.”

Back in the ring market, word had arrived ahead of them in the tiny feet of speculation and hung from awnings like drying apricots. People always think they deserve to be there when something important happens, and this weathered their disappointment by letting them tell the story wrong to the exact right audience.
