It was a thinning, the sound a thread makes when a little boy pulls it through a hole in his sweater and the sweater considers becoming something else. It was not urgent. It was patient, which was worse. Mara lifted the stabler and balanced its open jaw just above a seam-shoulder that had tried too often to be a road and failed and then decided to make the failure permanent. She did not close it. She looked at Bram, whose stick rested against his leg like a tame river, and he nodded once, not as license but as witness. A sheep with a burr in its flank turned its rectangular eye upon her and dipped its head, and that was all she was going to get from the wool.

“If you behave,” she said quietly to the tool, which was the only way she could behave herself, “I will find you something beautiful later to fasten that has no consequence. I will staple a ribbon to a child’s hair and you may preen.” The stabler warmed the way a face warms when you compliment the wrong thing but mean it kindly, and she closed the jaw on iron and air and wool together because there was a tuft caught on the stone and she would have been foolish not to include it in the bargain. The sigh moved through the ledges and through the chalk, which lifted in a draught and then settled into itself like a cat resettling in its own fur. The loose shape below stumbled over the suddenly well-behaved notch the seam made and broke into three smaller notions, each less convinced of its own inevitability than the last.

Corwin exhaled as if he had been holding his breath since the sea was invented. The Public Safety woman squinted down the slope and then up at Mara as if to say: I have a warehouse of rope and barrels of nails and none of them do what you just did, which is both infuriating and a relief. Bram did not move. The sheep moved in a way that made the ledges look briefly like grammar and then like melody again, and one of them bleated a sound that had the comfort of a closing door without the insult of being shut out. The iron’s story softened back down to where it could be ignored by a man buying a pie and cherished by a dog that knew the difference between weather and news.

“Do not do it again here,” Bram said, friendly as a fencepost. “You’ve set the staple deep because you included what the seam thinks of itself. That means if you fix another length too close you’ll make them call to each other and then we will have a wall where a seam belongs. People do not like walls unless they can paint them, and I do not wish to explain to the Council why we are suddenly a castle.”

“I have no interest in castles,” Mara said, and it was true until the moment the word made a structure in the air and she realized: a castle is only corners with better publicity. The stabler settled against her palm and breathed. It did that, sometimes, when it had eaten well. She wanted very much to laugh and did not, because of Corwin’s face, which had the look of a man who had just watched someone fix his job by accident. The Public Safety woman spoke first because that was her craft. “We will run rope down from the ledge,” she said, pointing, “and hang bells where the iron flinches. Your chalk circles can be made official. I can get the city to sign a paper that says we respect the difference between a road and a rut. It will make no difference to the wolves, but it will make a difference to men.”

The loose shape down on the flat did not dissolve so much as lose credibility. A plan undone. It slid toward the sea like an idea hoping salt would fix it, which never works and always looks elegant. The sheep watched it leave with the mild disdain of a creature that has survived a thousand versions of a thing and knows all their endings, and then they turned back toward their ledges and put their ears to stone again as if the seam had gone back to telling them a story worth being quiet for. Corwin put his hand on the iron the way a boy in church pats a carved saint when no one is looking. He nodded, small, as if the iron had told him something he had understood and promised not to repeat. He was not the sort of man who would keep that promise, but he was at least the sort who would be embarrassed when he broke it.

On the climb down, when the air stopped buzzing and the earth resumed its old habit of pretending it never speaks, Bram shouldered his stick and let a breath out as if someone had called his name from very far away and then decided it was a different Bram they wanted. “Night-stabler,” he said, not fussing over the word as if proud to be holding something old enough to splinter. “There was a woman once, up in Prent’s Fold, who bound storms. Not to the fence—don’t look at me like that, I can tell that’s where your head goes. She tied them to themselves. Gave the thunder back to the clouds and the clouds back to the thunder and told the hill to sit down and not take anything personally. It worked, until it didn’t. She did a fourth, after three, because somebody she liked was coming over the saddle and did not deserve to drown. She kept the storm for him and after that all our weather was tired for a year. Grain sulked. Children were listless. Even the dogs dreamed of shade. The hill forgave her, eventually, but it named a gully for her in a way that makes the gully a warning if you know your maps.”

“I like three,” Mara said, to make her mouth believe it. “I liked three in school, when teachers made us speak to be certain we had learned. Once to say it. Once to demonstrate it. Once to be sure we would remember the shape of the saying. Four is show-off business. Four is thinking you are the outside of your own life.” She gripped the tool until it ceased thinking about jumping.

Corwin caught up, wearing the look of someone about to make himself useful so that he could forgive himself later for having been frightened. “We will need to draft guidance,” he said, and Bram barked a laugh so abrupt the sheep on the ledge above them turned their heads as one. “No, listen,” Corwin went on, a man pleading with laughter to be kind. “If we are to tell people not to overfasten their corners, we have to define corner. If we are to tell them wolves can be undone by chalk and singing and that woman’s impossible device, we have to distribute chalk and bells and some species of patience. We have to tell people that they themselves are the best part of the fence and the worst, depending on the hour they wake.”

“Put all of that on a poster,” Mara said, and surprised herself by meaning no harm. “Add a picture of a lamb for the children to color. Add a corner—no, two—and a line in the middle one must not cross. Try to avoid words like mandate, which make people yawn and then rebel. Perhaps staple one to every door.” She knew she had said the word on purpose and did not apologize for it. He deserved to have his verbs stolen now and then.

They met the shepherds where the path widened into conversation. A woman with hair like old straw made new smiled at the stabler the way you smile at a very large sweet dog that hasn’t chosen a target yet. “Stabler?” she asked, and Mara nodded. “Good,” the woman said. “The iron will talk faster now it has found an ear that knows when to close.” She held out a hand. “Tamsin. I keep the bells from turning vain and the dogs from falling in love with their own work. If you need wool that has not yet learned bad habits, you ask me. If you need wool that has learned every habit and can teach you which ones are useful, you ask Calder, who has been old since birth and hasn’t noticed. We will make a calling cry you can hear in your kitchen when we need you. It will sound like the kettle behaving wrong. You will be disgusted by it and you will be quick.”

Mara felt her ribs grow a size and make room for a new kind of hurry. “If the iron asks and I am peeling potatoes,” she said, and left it there because that was a better prayer than anything with saints in it. Tamsin nodded as if Mara had passed some exam that had never been written down. Bram, looking relieved to let someone else stand in front, turned to Corwin and said, “Write your charter, binder-man, but add a clause that says we are permitted to not be the sort of people who need charters on Wednesdays. The hill doesn’t understand Wednesdays but it does like kindness. If you teach the city to do that, we might forgive it its squares.”

Back in the ring market, word had arrived ahead of them in the tiny feet of speculation and hung from awnings like drying apricots. People always think they deserve to be there when something important happens, and this weathered their disappointment by letting them tell the story wrong to the exact right audience. Laleh leaned in the doorway of the locksmith’s stall with her notebook folded and the pencil tucked behind her ear like a proposal she intended to reject out of affection. “Don’t,” she said as Mara came up the lane, soft as any prayer. “I know you have a speech about three and restraint and why walls are rude. Save it for the Council. Tell me instead what the iron said. Did it mention me. Did it praise my posture. Did it complain about the way we all walk on it with our heads too high.”

“It told a story about when it was a river,” Mara said, handing the other woman the saucer she had promised Bram and he had shoved back at her when she insisted on climbing again. “It told a story about steps. It did not mention you because it has decided not to flatter us in ways that make no difference. Your headline will have to do without references.”

Laleh grinned and made a face like she had just eaten a word that had improved her teeth. “You are cruel,” she said. “Thank you. Cruelty is a kindness in my trade. Do you know that three men today asked me to write their names near yours. As if I were a grocer and fame a loaf. I told one I would write him next to Bram so that he could feel tall. I told another I would write him next to Corwin because he would be misquoted forever and that was a sort of immortality. I told the last I would write him next to the sheep and he cried. You should stop making allegory in public. It confuses us.”

The bells at the seam were being strung by late afternoon, a pretty sound for an ugly purpose. The city had decided it would accept bells the way it had accepted saucers and saucer-women and fence-post poetry: with a shrug and then an opinion. Children stole pieces of chalk and drew circles around their own feet and declared themselves exempt from chores until the circles were scuffed. The locksmith’s pretty son presented Mara with a ring of keys not matched to anything in particular and said, “No one should go to the hill without jingling; the wolves dislike comedians.” She took it and felt how the cold metal made her tool sulk and smiled at the sulking because she was becoming that person, the one who found personality in steel and was not ashamed.

The first letter arrived that night from the coughing man who had given her the tool. It came folded around itself in a way that made you think it had been experimenting with other forms of envelope and had not liked them. It smelled of sachet and ash and, faintly, of sheep. The writing was thicker than she remembered, less frantic, more in conversation with itself. He did not sign. People who send important objects do not reveal themselves unless they mean to give you a second thing.

I called it a stabler for reasons that have nothing to do with pins, the letter said, as if indulging her backstory. In the language I am no longer allowed to speak in public, it is a person. It stabils, which is to say it makes the jostled remember that they have elbows and should keep them to themselves. It keeps that which will be kept. It is more patient than any of us. It has rules, which is useful, and appetites, which is not. You should feed it chores, not chores that someone else has failed to do—that will sour it—but chores that no one person could do without becoming insufferable. If you can tell the difference you will be fine, or as fine as any of us are. Do not, if you can help it, make it an heirloom. This is a short-term device. The long term belongs to nothing we can hold.

She read it twice and then tucked it between two saucers where it would be hard to find and easy to reach. She made a list: corners done, corners spared, corners that would ask her in their own time. She wrote in the margins: wolves, bells, chalk, Laleh, Corwin’s pen, Bram’s gully, Tamsin’s thread. She added at the bottom: dear. She did not cross it out. She drank water without tasting it, because her mouth had grown heavy with iron’s story and she needed to let it forget itself for a minute.

Sleep came only because the city demanded it. The city is a tyrant and a nanny; it bolts your door some nights whether you agree or not. She dreamed as if someone had borrowed her head to classify a museum: cases labeled ROUTINE and IMPULSE and SHEEP and MEN and WOLVES and LOVE, with index cards tucked under each with notes to the curator about what had been mis-shelved and what had been stolen and what had been stapled by mistake. In the dream a boy put his nose to the glass of LOVE and breathed on it, and an alarm went off in the next room where someone was cataloguing brass. She woke with the lingering sense that she had been useful to someone less careful than she would prefer.

Morning brought rain that behaved, which is to say it went where gravity told it and not where gossip suggested. The bells at the seam let themselves be quiet until a girl ran along them with a stick and made a song that had the exact number of notes necessary to get her scolded. Mara boiled water because she had promised the kettle a life of adventure and because Bram had threatened to appear without warning if she did not. He appeared exactly when it boiled, which is the sort of magic you can rely on when you have known a person for the right amount of weeks and also for your whole life. He did not knock. He held his hat by the brim like a creature and petted it absentmindedly as if it had been very brave out in the weather.

“They wrote a clause,” he said over the first cup, as if apologizing for somebody else’s handwriting. “Corwin and the Council. It says: ‘In the matter of corners, all citizens shall endeavor to leave some for the air to tuck itself into.’ It’s not bad. It’s a sentence that knows what it wants to do with itself. There’s a committee forming to define endeavor, of course.”

“Of course,” Mara said, fishing the letter from the saucers and sliding it across where Bram could put his finger on the place where a stranger had reminded them both that tools have tempers. “He says chores, not miracles. He says if I hand it a future to hold it will sulk until that future arrives and then drop it, which is a kind of justice and a kind of rudeness.”

Bram read and nodded. “He is right. There is something in this that does not like our myths. It will not hold a prophecy. It will not hold anyone’s hope if the hope has a face. It will hold exactly as long as kindness, which is to say until lunchtime and then again at tea.” He set the page down and took another mouth of coffee and then set that down, too, because the bell in his brain had been struck by a distant hand. “Hear that,” he said, and she did not, which frightened her more than the sound would have. He cocked his head. “A new wrong. Not wolves. Not path. Not iron being asked to be a spine again. Paper. Too much paper.”

It was astonishing how quickly the city could make a creature out of paper. By noon men and women who had never filled a form in complete sentences were collecting signatures with a fervor usually reserved for ship departures and births. They had found the quiet place at the heart of the Council’s clause and they had decided to make it shout. Petitions sprouted like mushrooms: to require bells on every belt, to forbid wolves from appearing in allegory in classrooms, to prevent sheep from receiving combs without a license, to commission a statue of a woman holding a stapler on the plinth where the man with the sword had looked tired for a century and a half. Laleh was in the square with a laugh that had borrowed gold and was lending it at interest. Corwin stood on the steps of the Council building with a face like weather, trying to remember the taste of authority while not tasting its salt too greedily. The Public Safety woman had stopped three arguments by reminding their loudest participants where they kept their spines. The petitions grew teeth. Paper makes edges if you stack it enough.

Mara did not intend to use the stabler on paper. That would be indecent, like wearing your grandmother’s pearls to a boxing match. She took it with her anyway and stood very still at the edge of the square the way you stand when a dance is happening that could become a fight. Bram drifted at an angle that kept him between a boy’s ruckus and an old woman’s indignation and made both of them steer better. The sheep did not come. The sheep had the better sense to be at the seam listening to iron’s memory instead of counting the ways a city can be foolish in public.

One petition in particular wound around the others like a more convincing vine. It made no demand and carried no signature lines. It was a shape, drawn with ink the color of nights in your childhood, the kind where your mother moved through the kitchen and said nothing because saying would have woken the smallest child and the smallest had been an angel all day. The shape had corners and then did not. It had a gate and then it had a wall and then it had a seam and then it had a road, and if you held your breath and squinted you could see the path-wolves trotting along its edges pleased as boys who have been told to take the long way on purpose. Underneath, someone had written Why Not. It was not a question. It was a dare.

Mara felt the tool in her pocket roll over and open one eye. She felt the crowd, that organism with too many hearts, loose itself toward the wrong.

“Yes,” Corwin said through his teeth, watching her take the step that made the square bite down instead of swallow. “Fine. Come and staple our courage to our better natures. Do it gently, if you love me at all.”

“I have never loved you at all,” Mara said with the easy emphasis friends get to borrow when they intend to hand it back later. She did not look for a post or a rug or a fence. She went to the drawn shape and put the stabler’s mouth on the corner where the wall had remembered it had been a gate and had been proud of the memory in a way that made it susceptible to flattery. She looked at Bram and he shook his head because this was paper and paper keeps grudges longer than iron. She looked at the Public Safety woman and she tilted her chin the way a dog does when it hears its favorite word and is uncertain whether it was truly spoken. She looked at the crowd and hated them a little for needing her, which is the right way to love a city.

She closed the jaw and the sigh folded the sound of the square back down into bodies. The drawn corner held. The gate did not become a wall. The seam did not forget itself into a road. The wolves that had been waiting in the tautness of air, in the impatience of men, lost interest like boys when you tell them the sweets will taste of cough medicine. The paper fluttered because paper must always pretend to be the wind in miniature. The petitions around it went on shouting in ink, but what they shouted had lost its verb. People looked sheepish and some of them looked like sheep, a little, which is what happens when you survive something you almost invited in. Corwin sat down on the steps and laughed until his eyes were wet and then stood up and pretended he had been conferring with someone important. Laleh came and looked and did not write and said, “I could kiss you and that would ruin us both, so instead I am going to drink all your coffee and misquote you on purpose.”

If the day had ended there, if the bell fence had found its pitch and the petitions had found their limits and the iron had told its story and slept, chaptering the afternoon into something like calm, the city would have gone to bed with a headache and woken with an anecdote. But the seam had decided it was a talker now, and talkers breed talk. Near twilight, when the clay arcades turn purple and the smell of cinnamon shifts into the smell of sums being done and sums being lied about, a sound came—not from the hill and not from the square. From the water. A bell without a hand. A toll that had never been taught politeness. The sea began to ring.

Bram and Mara both looked up as if the sky had said their names, and Corwin finally did the one thing he was best built for and least praised for: he moved a crowd without being seen to move it. The Public Safety woman had men on the bell fence in a breath and women with chalk at the quays in two and by the third someone had decided to lower the harbor chain, which had always been ornamental but had liked to dream. The sheep arrived in a hurry that made no hooves sound, and you knew, seeing them, that this was their country in a way that streets never would be. Their wool had taken on the light of cockleshells. Their eyes were enormous doors. They went ahead without us and stood with their sleeves rolled up to their knees at the lip of the tide.

The bell the sea rang was not ours. It belonged to something that had been promised a long time ago and had come at last to collect, tired of our delays. The sound made tin taste of apples. It made shore birds forget their debts. It made a woman at the fish stall drop a knife and swear as if swearing were a prayer and prayers had just reminded her of how to be useful. Bruises hummed under shirts and were briefly proud. The stabler burned hot in Mara’s coat, and for the first time she did not know which way to point its mouth.

“What is it,” Corwin said, and he said it to Bram because this was not for pen or binder. Bram, who had more names for wrongs than anyone Mara had met and a calm for each, looked at the water and did not look away when it bucked like an animal with the bridle wrong.

“Harbor-will,” he said, and took off his hat because some words require that ritual even on weekdays. “Old pledge. The first men who stacked shields into a staircase stood at that chain and told the sea that if it wanted their iron it could have it but it would have to wait until they had done with it. The sea does not like to wait. It has been patient for a century and a half, and now it has scented our fussing and decided to try again. It will not take the iron. Not all of it. It will try to take our habit of thinking we can tell it when.”

The sea sent a sheet up the chain that roared without spray, as if water had finally learned indoor manners. The sheep bleated a chord that made sailors cry for their mothers and then be embarrassed forever. The chain, which had been a prop in civic plays and a place to put your foot when telling a story to a child, stood into the sound and did not break. It did something worse. It learned the note and hummed back. The will in it woke, with a stretch like a man who has slept badly and is promised a good chair.

“Circles,” the Public Safety woman barked, and the chalk women did their work without apology even though chalk and tide do not respect each other. “Corners,” Corwin said at the same time, almost without meaning to, because even a wave must decide what shape to take when it meets a quay. “Do not staple,” Bram said very quietly to Mara, and she would have been offended at being told her own business if fear had not curdled her blood into something obedient. “Not the water. Not a bell that has no handle. If you fasten this, the sea will take your word as bond and we will never eat mackerel again.”

“What do I do,” she asked him, for once not because she wanted to hear his sentences but because she could not find her own. Bram’s eyes were full of ships he would never sail. He put his fingers about an inch apart and made a shape in the air. “You staple me,” he said. “To the post. For three breaths. Only three. I will whistle and the chain will remember that it was meant to be friend and not father. Then you take the staple out. This one you take out.” He held out his arm and it was an old arm and also it was a stick. He smelled like wet wool that knows the story of its own lanolin.

She had never un-stapled. She had assumed that was work for decay and time and salt. She reached for the letter opener, the bone-handled maybe-knife she had used on cinnamon toast and once to show a boy that paper is more dangerous than it looks. It had a notch near the tip, a small cunning smile she had never understood. When she slid it into the stabler’s mouth, the tool sighed in a different octave and her hands knew without thinking how to set a seam loose. She had not been taught. The instruments taught each other while she slept, the way they always do if they share a drawer.

She pressed him to the quay. The sigh went out under his skin and into the post and made them family. He whistled the way he had whistled for wolves’ thoughts earlier but differently, with a flattery in it that made water preen. The chain forgot that it had been counted and remembered that once it had been sung. The sea lifted and considered and put its hand down. The bell hushed—not because it had been answered, but because it had been offered a better story. “Now,” Bram said, not loud, and she slid the bone under the staple-that-wasn’t and lifted, and the sense of the thing let go and ran away like a child who has discovered that its prank has stopped being a game.

The sea went back to being too much for everyone. The sheep went back to being good at their work and indifferent to being honored for it. Corwin sat because his legs had endured too much being a public servant for one day. The Public Safety woman wrote down three things on the back of her hand and smudged them and wrote them again. Laleh appeared with hair wet at the ends and wrote a line that would later read as calm and had not been. The chain drooped into the tolerance we call slack. Mara wiped the bone clean on her skirt and had no regret for the stain.

“You did not keep me,” Bram said, checking his arm as if it were a separate creature and he a farmer at inspection, and she shrugged and then shook because sometimes what you have done arrives at your body late. “You asked me to be kept,” she said, stubborn as any corner. “There is a difference.” He put his hat back on because some men cannot endure gratitude in the open air and need brim for it.

Night found the city tired and pleased to be. The petitions thinned and went to bed under dishes. The seam hummed a lullaby stolen from a shepherd long gone. Wolves lay in their chalk circles and complained of boredom to no one in particular. The bell fence wore fog and looked holy. In her kitchen, Mara put the stabler and the bone into the sink together and felt them knock teeth, an intimate and irritating sound. She set the saucers back into their pattern and found, in the un-useful space where the pattern failed itself and the table insisted on being wood, a place where her hand could rest and mean it. She ate bread without butter and did not apologize to anyone for liking it. She put wool beside the letter and the letter beside the spoon and the spoon beside the day and decided, not for the first time, that being tired was a kind of prayer that the morning generally granted.

There is no moral for a day like this. The best you can do is promise to tell it true later, and then keep finding ways to keep your later from becoming a rut. The city slept the way a pen runs dry: usefully. The sea, having been flattered, permitted itself to forget we existed until it needed us to make a story more interesting. Above, in the quarry, sheep pressed their heads to iron and dreamed of grass because everyone dreams of the thing they have already. Bram lay on his side with his stick between his knees like a fence he needed to keep nearby so he didn’t dream of breaking it. Corwin dreamed of signing his own name in a ledger that forgave him for ignorance and felt, the moment before waking, what it would be like to mean it. And Mara, in the small upslope of an apartment that had once been a broom closet and had become a bridge, slept between her tools as if between two versions of herself and woke at dawn with the taste of bells in her teeth and the certainty that the quiet between three and four would not belong to any creature tomorrow.

Mara woke from a dream in which saucers had argued about gravity and the argument had left a taste of steel on her tongue, and it took a minute for her to be certain that the mouthful of bells she carried into the day belonged to night and not to a mistake she had made just now with her teeth. The tool in the sink had shifted to the far side of the basin as if preferring the company of the bone-handled letter opener, which made domestic sense in the way a spoon decides a drawer is friendlier if a whisk is nearby. She put water on because Bram would arrive as if tied to the boil, and while she waited she did something she had only thought about, which was to ask the bone to teach her a rule. She slid it into the stabler’s jaw and felt the little notch find a place like a tongue finding the sweet seed in a pomegranate, and she closed her eyes and pictured the seam at the quay where she had fastened Bram to the post for three breaths because he had asked. The notch warmed, and the muscles along her thumb told her unfastening has a different courage in it than fastening, and the water began to complain in the pot in the exact voice of Tamsin’s promised calling-cry and then remembered itself and behaved. She did not try to unmake anything that did not ask. She had learned to listen for asking the way some people learned to watch for a child’s lie to go glossy before it fell apart, and it made her tired to admit that what she had of wisdom had been purchased with that kind of eavesdropping.

Bram did not knock, which meant that something had gone right in the night and he had saved the knocking for the day when news would come in a bad hat. He put his stick on the table the way a man lays a violin down because he intends to tell someone why he no longer plays and then hopes they interrupt him before he has to. “The chain slept,” he said, accepting his cup with his mouth already shaped around thank you and not using the words in case it dented them, “and the wolves grumbled and lay in their circles and tried to trick each other and were bored by their cleverness. Tamsin says the iron told a story about ships that begins with the word no and ends with the word maybe and she is happier than I have seen her since her dog decided to like a baby. How is your convalescent instrument.”

“It sulks if I group it with cutlery but preens if I make it think it is an heirloom,” she said, and then would not let her face do the work of a smile, because there is a moment after a night when a sea has rung at you when your mouth should not lie even to comfort a friend. “The bone has a notch for undoing. It taught me while I slept, which is rude and a kindness. It will not release a seam if I fastened it for pride. It will only let go if I ask it to forgive me for making a choice it knows I made under duress. It has opinions and they are petty and right.”

Bram lifted the bone, which was a delicate thing, heavier near the unnecessary beauty at the butt, and balanced it along his knuckles until it told him to be careful and he obeyed before he knew he had. “Everything that undoes has opinions,” he said. “That is why promise-breakers in the hills are made to tell the same story of their breaking to three different children on three different days; if the children believe the breaker, the promise was faulty and can be undone without cursing the weather. If one child finds a selfishness the other two did not see, the breaker keeps their shame for a while like a stone in a pocket to keep him from walking too fast into comfort. You should not use the bone on Wednesdays unless you are prepared to have your neighbors tell you later that they felt treacherous all afternoon and could not say why.”

The kettle did an ungainly thing with steam that smelled, faintly, of wool, which meant the hill had breathed and the city had noticed. Mara poured and found the luxurious quiet that attends a day that intends to be difficult and is gentleman enough to give you coffee first. Corwin arrived with a newspaper under his arm and a page of the charter folded open to another page that scolded the public in an approachable font, and he stood with his back to the sink as if it were a door to a garden and he was making a point of not leaving as a way of showing his good breeding. “We are to sign,” he said without invoking a subject for his verb because he had decided the city counted as that when he was in her kitchen. “At noon, in the arcades, with the bells strung and the sheep obliging us by not being late. The clause about corners has survived with fewer teeth marks than I expected. The clause about not attaching bells to infants in their prams has caused a rift with a certain class of parent. I will stand on a crate and say endeavor as if it meant love and hope the crowd knows the difference, which it does not.”

He put the paper down, and the headline Laleh had written about the sea without naming it like a person who knew the force of proper nouns did a small bow across the grain of Mara’s table. The pretty son of the locksmith arrived in the door in a tie askew and a question already written on his face that had nothing to do with keys. He was the sort of boy who made women who had made their peace with practical shoes reconsider laces, and he was the sort of boy who did not know it yet, which is the only safe version. “May I borrow a sliver,” he asked, pointing not to the stabler but to the bone. “All I need is the smile on the tip. A bit of steel to lay in wax, for a cast. Someone is making a picking tool that undoes latches in the name of liberty and the name of liberty is a different man every afternoon. They asked me to cut a groove because I cut grooves the way my mother cut bread, without wasting the middle. I told them no, and they told me they would get it somewhere else, and I came here to be told I was right and to be called a fool if there is a third choice I do not see.”

Mara did not hand him the bone because there are errands that should make a boy walk to someone older than desire, and she did not send him away because she remembered being the sort of person who wanted to be useful and could be tricked by any tool that shaped its mouth in need. She put her fingers around the opener’s plain side and felt it say today is for refusals with gentle syllables, the way a grandmother tells a child no with a story about a fox, and she gave the boy the saucer that had been cracked handsomely and said, “Practice your groove on this. A plate knows what it is to be asked to become something it is not and will teach you patience without giving you everything. If they ask you again, send them to me or to Tamsin. If they go to the men who sell rope in the alley behind the coops, the rope will learn their names before they know it and will expect to be paid in something other than coin.”

He looked wounded in the way you can be wounded when you came for sanction and were given a lesson, and then he looked proud because the lesson had used him as if he were already real. He took the saucer, which shaped itself to him as if it had been looking for a young hand as a justification, and he bowed in the way boys forget how to do the moment someone lets them start wearing black, and he left with a promise to show her the groove and not to sell it to anybody with a hat that looked like it had been worn by three generations of men who had not read a book.

The square filled before the bells had finished practicing being polite, and it had that low thrum a market gets when everyone brings their very best disagreement and arranges it around fruit. The sheep came in a cluster that was not exactly a circle and not exactly an argument; they paused where the canvas made its favorite crease and laid their heads together in a way that made you want to be loved by something without hands. The charter lay on a table the grocer brought and was weighted at one corner with a bag of sugar and at another with a stone that had been a doorstop for so long it had opinions about thresholds. Corwin stood up on the crate and made endeavor sound like please, and the Public Safety woman stood beside him with her chalk in hand as if at any moment language might need to be put on the ground for the sake of a useful shape, and Laleh stood behind with a pencil that did not like lying and was prepared to be forced if it made the truth kinder.

Mara stood among the neighbors and resisted the honest tug of the tool in her pocket toward any place where two things wanted to pretend they had always been one thing, and she watched as the city did what cities do when presented with a promise disguised as prose: it sighed, it cracked a joke, it remembered a funeral, it leaned forward like men at a window when a cat attempts something athletic across the street. Bram took up a corner of the table because even a charter deserves a shepherd, and the sheep leader with the scar that would not be tamed put a hoof on the step and stared with a politeness that could be mistaken for dullness by anyone who had not watched a flock decide where to sleep. The clause about corners was read and came out of a different mouth than the one that had written it and still survived because the crowd had heard themselves in it in the weeks when they had stood near a corner and felt the weather settle there to rest. The clause about bells was read and a man who had been drunk on bells for three days shouted that he had been cured of the thirst by the sight of his neighbor’s hat adorned with two and everyone made a helpful noise that was not forgiveness and was better.

When it was Mara’s turn to come up the crate because the City needs to use small, familiar bodies to trick itself into a sense of continuity, she did not recite three. She thought of doing it and then she remembered the way Bram had said the name of the woman who had tied a storm to itself and made weather sulk for a year, and she told them instead about unfastening and about the way saying yes and then no to the same seam makes a room feel like a courtroom. She told them about the bone and the notch and the rule she had learned before coffee, that you should not undo in pride what you did in fear and vice versa, and if you cannot tell which you did, you should wait with your hand on the table until you can. She said the word mercy aloud and did not apologize for it. They listened as they always listen when the thing is the size of their kitchen and not the size of a wall.

After, while people formed a polite war to sign the charter without looking like exactly the sort of person who enjoys signing charters, Tamsin arrived with a coil of red thread fat as a cordial and wrapped it once around the leg of the table and once around her own wrist and twice around the bag of sugar, and she looked at Mara with a humor that came from living far from metaphor and said, “We went up to the far ledge and found a thing that is going to try to be a habit while we are busy with paper. There is a place where the seam would like to split itself and roll down like a rug toward the sea and become useful as a common path for men who carry loads too heavy for kindness. It is singing in thirds. That is the kind of singing stone does when it thinks about giving in. The sheep do not like it. If you can spare your scarred friend and your man with the chalk and your boy with the questions and that person with the pen who keeps saying deliverable as if it were holy, we would like to take them all up after soup and ask the seam to be unreasonable for a bit longer.”

Soup made the crowd consider themselves loved, which is the easiest way to get them to forgive the city for making them assemble in weather. Mara found the kettle at one end of the arcades like a defeated cannon and Corwin found ladles in a warehouse that had never before believed it contained anything the world would eat, and Laleh, whose expertise did not extend to broth, found an elderly man who had been waiting a long time to be asked to stir and let him tell everyone next to him how to make a stock without stock until they felt nourished by stories and not by vegetables. The soup had the taste of a compromise that had cooked long enough to be its own kind of food, and afterward the uphill exodus had the feel of a wedding procession no one had planned and everyone remembered from a dream.

Up high, the seam sounded like a machine learning to be a person in an unsatisfactory novel and like a person learning to be a machine in the sort of poem people recite at wakes because it is easier than silence. The sheep stood in two lines that made a narrow corridor for air and a broad gate for meaning, and Tamsin’s bell hung from a post and refused to ring out of loyalty to the kind of quiet the hill prefers. The place she had spoken of was a kink in the iron where the stone had learned men’s weight as a dialect and was now tempted by the fluency of surrender. The kink tugged at itself, and the ground near it had taken to leaning, a slouch that invited hooves to make it worse. Bram closed one eye and held his stick like a tuning fork and the Public Safety woman drew a circle not on the ground this time but in the air with her hand, and Corwin—who had not argued about coming because even a binder wants to be early for once when a page might change underneath his palm—stood with his mouth closed on purpose and his pen nowhere near thought.

Mara did not put the stabler on the seam because the seam had not asked yet, and she did not tap the bone against the tool to remind it of their agreement because that would have been a performance and the iron disliked theater when it was in pain. She touched the kink and tried to be quiet in all the places Tamsin respected, and she felt the ask in it come reluctant and shy as a child who apologizes because someone taught it to, not because it understands. The iron did not want to be brave. It wanted to be congratulated for considering it. She had known men and women who were made of that. It made her tender to feel it in a seam.

“Not this,” she said, the way you say to a cat about to make a mess of a guest’s coat, but with more respect because the seam was older than cats and had been polite longer. “Not this time. There is another path we can give the heavy men. Corwin, do you have rope. You always have rope. It is one of the ways you make it easy for us to forgive you.”

Corwin did not have rope because he never has exactly the thing he would be proudest to have, but he had forms with string and the string was stronger than it looks when it wants to prove a point, and Tamsin had thread that had remembered the weight of a hundred bells and therefore was arrogant enough to hold more. They lashed together a courtesy and slung it across a lower shelf of stone and made a way that was not the seam and would do for any man who could be persuaded he would get back down the hill alive if he obeyed a rule for as long as it took to sing a song. The seam eased in the way a child does when you replace a sweet with a story. Mara put the stabler to the air near the kink and closed it on nothing and listened to the sigh go out and come back like her breath after a hill she should not have climbed and felt the iron believe itself again in this place and be glad.

On the way down, the pretty son of the locksmith appeared from a ledge where he had obviously been practicing being older than his mother and he held out the saucer she had given him and showed her the groove. It was a handsome curve, too shallow to hold a sin and too bold to be ashamed of itself, and he had cut it with a patience she had only ever seen in gardeners and men who change their own minds. “They came back,” he said in a rush that made his words step on each other like cousins, “with money and with a promise they did not intend to keep about using it to free doors that had been shut by people with unclean intent and I told them to eat a shoe. I returned the coin to the smallest one who had the kindest mouth and said I would carve him a handle instead that fit a door that fit a room that fit a table where he could stop thinking he had the right to walk in and tell other people to be rearranged. He did not like my speech, but the coin felt what it feels when it has done wrong and wanted to be in its own pocket and I let it.”

Mara took the saucer and touched the groove and felt how the curve had turned the broken into art without teaching it any lies about utility. She wanted to say three things at once—the first about pride, the second about safety, the third about a time when she had cut a line in a piece of paper because she could not find a notebook and how that line had turned into a week and a sea—and so she said none and instead asked him if he would like to go down into the ring and hold a bell for an hour, because that was a way to make a boy feel seen without making him a hero, which is a rudeness.

The charter signing, when they did it after soup and after the hill had been persuaded to be boring again, had the ceremony of children promising not to peek on their birthdays. People lined the page with names that looked like fields and names that looked like law and names that looked like birds that would not live even into next spring, and they flourished their pens and they compromised their spelling and they made marks that would stand in for hands when hands were elsewhere, and Corwin endured it with patience that brought tears to a man nearby who had not expected to feel anything but the draft. The sheep were offered wreaths of thyme because no one can entirely resist improving nature with an herb, and they ate them because that is what you do when a human offers you food with sincerity, and then they left a pile of wool near the table and Tamsin took it and tied pieces to the wrists of the children who hung back and pretended not to mind.

Night came with rain that had learned to find corners and be tender there, and in the dark a new wrong slipped along the edges of roofs with the particular silence of malice trying to make itself look like weather. There were men and women who had decided they did not care to read a charter and had learned very quickly where the bone’s notch found its work, and they had nothing so decent as a tool to help them; they had fingers that had cut buttons from coats in markets and minds that had practiced being pleased by slack. They chose two corners, then six, then sixteen, and undid the holding Mara had done as if snapping thread and saying see, see, see, the seam only held because someone was watching. The city woke in the wrong places, at stairheads and at the backs of cupboards where the darkness should be lazy, and bells answered in disgust and then in horror, and by the time the Public Safety woman had men out with chalk and none of it doing any good because chalk is a sermon and you cannot preach to someone whose face is turned to the wall, the kettle in Mara’s kitchen made the sound Tamsin had promised and made it twice because once would have been manners and tonight they needed something more like urgency.

Out in the arcades Laleh lit a candle and held it under her chin until she looked like an idea everyone had had and not credited, and she told three boys to fetch sugar and three girls to bring string and she told a woman with a scar like a comma on her wrist to stand in the center of the square and be an object to gather around, and she sent a child who had learned to run without moving his shoulders too much to Bram’s door with no words, and she went to Corwin and took his pen out of his hand and put it behind her ear so he would remember how to speak without writing first. Mara took the tool in one hand and the bone in the other and went where people had allowed the wrong to begin because the wrong is always more polite there and less energetic and therefore easier to embarrass.

The corners they had undone were the small domestic kind, the remedying sort that had kept a mat from sliding and a door from ever so slightly denying entry to a man who would later be thankful for the delay. She fixed two and refused a third and sweet-talked a fourth and found that her anger made the tool heavy and her sorrow made the bone kind. Bram arrived with his stick and a dog that had been a joke that morning and was a hero tonight and he put his body in a threshold and made it a corner by wanting something good very hard, and the wrong changed its mind about whether this was going to be easy and went across the square to find a different kind of slack. Corwin, who is always at his best an hour after he is forgiven, found a boy with chalk and taught him to draw a circle around the place where a door meets a wall so that when a hand touched it from the outside the chalk would tell it that hands are for holding and not for taking, and the boy glowed like a coal in a pocket.

It took until rain gave up and learned humility again. It took until the string across the square acquired knots the shape of excuses and the shape of prayers, and Laleh recorded neither because it is not the job of newspapers to make us look worse than we are when we will do that for ourselves by noon. It took until the child with the good running told Tamsin that the kettle had been telling secrets and Tamsin came with thread on both wrists and said names to the wrong that made it blush, because wrong has a body and it hates to be called old. They caught two of the people who had undone corners and discovered, once again, that villains are very boring in their particulars and very interesting in their reasons; one said they did it because they wanted the sheep to like us more if our corners were loose, and one said they did it because he hated doors that open when you push instead of when you pull. They were taken home by neighbors who had their names and who would not let them become the sort of men who belong to stories.

In the morning someone had chalked on Mara’s stoop three questions that were not questions and looked like they had come from a school where pens were treated like we treat birds, with food and hands always the same temperature. It said: Who asked you to keep us. What will you do when the tool runs out. Who will unfasten you when you are the seam. She stepped over them because breakfast, and because if she did not eat she would answer the chalk and the chalk would be too pleased with itself and go write it at the corner near the bakery where children like to scuff and could not be trusted not to improve it with dragons. She boiled water and ate bread without butter again and put the wool Tamsin had tied to her wrist around the handle of the stabler and watched it look better when it was less certain of itself, which is a look she had admired in men and loathed in guns.

The note came from the coughing man before noon, folded the way a person folds when they apologize to a chair for bumping it with their hip, and it told her a thing that made her sit down without being taught by her knees first. There is a brother to a stabler, he wrote, and he drew a picture bad enough to be honest and good enough to be useful, and it had a jaw too, but its jaw closed the other way, and it did not sigh, it hissed, and it did not bind, it taught a thing how to forget how to be two when it had been two for good reasons. He called it a separator, which was a true name and a treacherous one, and he told her a man had been seen with one near the ring road seven years ago when a bridge had chosen not to fall until later and was persuaded to do now what it had planned to do after the feast, and that the man had not been seen again because sometimes a city, out of love, will seat a person in a chair and put a biscuit in their hand and wait with them until they forget why they had left the house at all.

Mara went to find Corwin because there are things you should not keep to yourself even if you can make a joke about saucers later, and she carried the letter and the bad picture and the bone inside her coat like she would a baby if she had ever had the chance to make that mistake, and she found him at the Council building not reading a petition but watching a crack in the stone as if it had written to him personally. He took the paper and did not pretend to be surprised because good officials practice their face until surprise is a private hobby, and he did the good thing he does sometimes which is not to speak until everyone else in the room has forgotten why they wanted to. “We will be asked,” he said at last, “to get one. Someone with donations and blue ink will think owning a separator makes us strong. We will be told it is for emergencies. We will be shown a wall with a door that should be open and an old woman who cannot get in because the door has swollen with weather and we will be told we are cruel if we do not use the hiss. I need you to tell me no.”

She said no in three ways, because she knows a bureaucrat must take no like medicine and then like dessert and then like brandy if he is to be cured. She said no because there is a difference between removing a hand and removing a habit and only one keeps you from ever taking a hand again when it is offered. She said no because there are seams in men and women that should be allowed to keep their secrets even when they have been careless with the secrets of others. She said no because she loved him, which is to say she trusted him to tell her, later, when she was wrong, and to sit with her in a kitchen while the kettle admitted it had been wrong about itself again.

They put the charter up on the wall of the clay arcades and tied it with four woolen bands at the corners so it would be hard to pretend it had flown away by itself when the first westerly came, and Laleh ran her fingers along the edges as if teaching the paper to tolerate hands, and on the first night afterward the sea was quiet, the wolves were bored, the petition men went home and swept, and the sheep slept as if the iron had told them a bedtime story about a hill that had learned the trick of staying exactly the same through four different kinds of weather and had not been punished by a god for it. Mara washed two saucers because they had been out in the air and had collected a rumor and she is particular about rumor on plates, and she set the tool on the towel and told it something no one had asked her: You are not my life. You are a way my life is being useful and I will not forgive you if you try to become more than that. The tool was heavy and warm and pretended not to hear, which was an improvement in their conversations. Bram sat on her step and did not knock and combed the dog’s ears with his fingers until the dog sighed in his sleep as if someone had tied a ribbon on a memory and put it back on the correct shelf.

In the days that followed the city learned to say endeavor as if it meant promise and to say mercy as if it meant arithmetic, which it does if you have ever counted someone’s faults and found yourself better at math than you like. The bell fence caught three wrongs before breakfast one morning because wrong is always hungrier than we are, and Tamsin’s thread tied itself into a phrase a girl could hum while sweeping, and the Public Safety woman developed a way to stand with her arms that made men with tools feel they were holding toys, which is a talent handed down from mothers to daughters when no one is watching. The pretty son of the locksmith made a key that opened nothing and he wore it around his neck and boys he used to be cousins with patted it and tried to ask without asking what it meant, and he told them it meant he could be relied upon not to open anything that had been closed with regret, and that sort of honesty does something to a neighborhood that paint cannot.

Then, because ordinary is always brief even when you wish it were not, the kettle cried Tamsin’s wrong with the note that meant hurry and politeness both, and the dog lifted his head because he had dreamed the cry at the seam and was glad to be asked for work by a sound he recognized, and Corwin appeared not at her door but at the corner because he had learned what corners to stand in when he did not want to be noticed by the wrong people, and Bram had the look of a man whose stick had said a Particular will show itself and if we do not greet it it will put a hat on and we will not recognize our own fortune when it knocks. The letter from the coughing man lay on the saucers like a promise someone else would have to keep, and Mara put the bone beside it and took the stabler in both hands and said aloud the quiet thing that lets a person walk into a version of their life that would once have frightened them: I will endeavor. I will keep some corners for the air. I will staple you to your good sense if you make me ask twice. I will ask someone to unfasten me when I am the seam. She said it without making a speech of it and the room believed her, and the city, which is nosy, heard.

The summons carried that unnerving mixture of hurry and patience that meant the hill had noticed a wrong and the city was still deciding whether to be embarrassed by it. Mara stepped into the corridor with her coat already on because her hands had learned, in the last weeks, how to move before her mind wanted to admit she had decided, and she found Bram at the corner in that shepherd’s half-shadow he made when he intended to usher a day toward a better ending. Corwin waited ten feet off with his pen put away and his attention out in front of him like a lantern, and the Public Safety woman—who, it turned out, had a name after all and was irritated with herself for not having given it sooner—Hesta, nodded as if she could make the morning bow to a sensible timetable with mere chin. Tamsin’s thread flashed at her wrists like a pair of small, red thoughts. “It isn’t wolves,” Hesta said before anyone could poach her business with worse vocabulary. “Something is teaching the edges to be proud.”

They followed the sound of bells thinking it over and turned under the brick arch by the Registry, where men who liked to be obeyed as a profession had kept maps on the walls so long that maps had learned a smell from the rooms. The wrong had come for the place where names are married to numbers and numbers persuade doors to behave, and it had been genial about it in the way a con is genial. House plates lay on the ground separated from their screws as if the two had been introduced at a dance and had mutually agreed that they were better off as acquaintances. A row of files leaned like men at a harbor rail and then leaned a little farther, and a clerk put his hand out to prevent a spill and his hand hovered half an inch from the paper without touching because he could not remember if he was allowed. On the wall where the city kept its sense of itself as a whole, the map had curled at the edges and made a noise like a drying leaf. The chalk circles Hesta had ordered drawn at the Registry’s four corners had fallen open into parentheses and then into commas someone had removed from their sentences out of spite. “No,” Bram said under his breath, not as spell but as courtesy, and the wrong breathed in his face, cool and smug, the way vinegar sits in a bowl and pretends to be a sauce.

The first hiss came invisible and traveled through the frame of the Registry door the way a rumor travels through a family: in the grain, humming, persuasive. A man stood just inside that door and held in his hand a tool that had not been made for kitchens or quarries or anyone who respected the difference between keeping and owning. It had a jaw, yes, but its jaw closed backward, as if it preferred to teach things how to come apart than to show them how to stay. It exhaled a thin thread of white that was not smoke and not steam and smelled faintly of lemon gone wrong. He was not what villains ought to look like; he had good shoes and a coat that had been brushed, and his hat had a ribbon a woman with taste had chosen. He looked like a man you would ask to sign a paper because you believed handwriting could be an antidote to mischief. “Sir,” Corwin said, stepping forward with his open hands the way he did when he intended to hide his authority in his finger joints, “you will put that down and you will tell me your name and you will sit, and if you are lucky we will make tea and call this a misunderstanding.”

The man smiled the way a person smiles when he has taught his face to pass for humility. “It is a misunderstanding,” he said with the ease of someone who tells his own stories in court. “I am separating error from habit. I am un-binding the city from the lies you bind it with. There is a law against fastening what should have been allowed to find its own shape. You have been busy with staples. Permit a correction.” He pressed the jaw to the edge of the map—just to the corner where the ring market made its round flirtation with the clay arcades—and the hiss went out so quietly that a child coloring under a table would not have been startled, and the paper lifted its corner and decided it preferred to be a sheet. Mara felt her hand go to her pocket because there are gestures your body performs on your behalf when it senses that your thinking is about to be laggard.

“Particular,” Bram said, and the word came out in him like an old cough he had learned to like because it signaled thinking, and the man’s eyes slipped to him as if bothered to have been named so quickly. “He is not a wolf and not a bell. He is the argument that every field, seen from far enough, is a patchwork without stitches, and that stitches are an insult. He is here to teach us how to call each square of grass by a different surname.”

“You shouldn’t give your wrongs names in public,” Hesta said, chalk poised. “They will come when called. Sir, I will ask again. Put your tool down. You are not city staff. You do not know how the Registry tolerates our bad habits. If you unfasten this map entirely, we will not remember which way the door is supposed to swing.”

The man tilted the hiss’s jaw toward a set of drawers that had been a coherent idea for three generations and exhaled. Two drawers eased away from the cabinet and let their labels slide loose so that the papers within became orphans of their own vocabulary. He took a step as if to test the floor for obedience and the floor, which had been good all morning, decided to become four planks instead of a surface. Mara saw fear on Corwin’s face not because a stranger had brought a device into his Registry but because he had expected the day to be about signing and soup and now it was about asking people to agree to be one thing when they had been something else for a very long time.

Mara did not draw her tool like a sheriff, because the city would have laughed and that sort of laugh is hard to un-hear when you need to be obeyed. She took the stabler out and held it low and felt it turn in her grip the way a riverstone rolls in a palm to find the temperature of a hand it likes. The hiss turned its mouth toward her in a little mockery of friendliness, and the man holding it inclined his head as if greeting a colleague. “You have the twin,” he said. “You have the lie. Put it away. Let this place unlearn its bad marriages.”

“Who taught you that word,” Mara asked, feeling the bone-handled opener slide along the seam of her coat as if it would prefer to be first to the table if there were going to be lessons. “Who told you the device hisses because it is righteous and not because it is bored. Do you know what happens when you separate more than you understand. You end up alone in a kitchen praising your own pantry for its independence.”

He did not like the laughter that arrived at the edges of the Registry when she said that because it came from clerks who had not had the courage to laugh at him when he arrived. “You have fastened wolves to chalk circles,” he said, hissing at the map again and making the markets flutter. “You have attached a chain to a promise as if promises appreciate hardware. You have stapled a man to a quay. I will not let you staple a city to your nervousness about change. There is a purer way.”

Tamsin’s thread knocked against itself on her wrist and made a small cadence that meant be less theatrical and more useful. “Sallying on about purity is how we broke half a hillside twenty years ago,” she said, stepping past Hesta and putting herself between the man and the drawers he had freed. “Iron likes to remember. Paper likes to warm itself against other paper. Wool likes to keep certain things in the same place for a hundred winters. If you intend to be in this town after supper you are going to have to be less interested in clean lines and more interested in soup.”

Mara set the stabler’s jaw on the corner of the map where the hiss had taught it to flirt with separation and closed it. The sigh climbed the wall with the kind of patience you learn from upholsterers and from old women who mend quilts with their hands and their tongues held a certain way, and the paper laid itself back into its old compromise. The man with the hiss grinned and moved quickly to another corner because wrongs are happiest when they can keep you turning, and Hesta stepped where he stepped and left chalk on the floor in a curve that dissuaded the boards from thinking of themselves as planks, and Bram whistled low the way he does when he wants a flock to notice a dog from the corner of their vision and be pleased by the competence of dogs, and three clerks put their hands on the drawers and reminded them that names and numbers, mismatched as they are, can learn to be cousins.

It would have been a dance if it had not been an insult. The man lifted the hiss and taught a hinge to forget what it meant to be hinge, and Mara took the thrust of that forgetting and stapled it to a memory she found in the air, something the Registry had kept without filing: the sound of a baby being named by a grandmother who had not been asked permission. The hinge took the memory and stayed in its pocket. The man hissed at a line on the floor that had taught children where to wait when they practiced manners, and Tamsin bent and tied her thread to the line and to her own wrist and stood and made patience fashionable. The man hissed at the corner of a book where the City had once written down a list of streets that wanted new names, and Laleh, who had arrived breathless and furious that the Registry should get to have the news first, leaned on the book and scribbled two syllables in a margin and made the book laugh and therefore unwilling to be persuaded that paper prefers to be alone.

“Who sent you,” Corwin asked the man during a moment when more than three people had their mouths closed at once. “If you say the Council you are a liar without imagination, and if you say my mother I will take you to her and she will separate your head from your reputation and give your reputation to a cat.”

The man looked disappointed that he had not frightened anyone properly and satisfied that he had unfastened enough familiarity for breakfast. “I was sent by the truth,” he said, and Hesta, who is not given to pearls of any kind, rolled her eyes so emphatically that a girl across the room did it too out of admiration. “The truth that your corners are crutches. The truth that your bells are vanity. The truth that a seam is only a habit you have taught iron and iron should be allowed to dress itself in water if it likes. The truth that sheep are just wolves who were given good press. The truth that the world was meant to come apart gracefully and perhaps singing.”

Bram made a noise she had not heard before, half laugh and half sorrow, and the wrong in the room ate it with relish. Mara felt, in the small bones across the back of her hand, the way the stabler bristled at the notion that it existed for lies. She felt, as a smaller and more treacherous feeling, the way that hiss made sense when pressed against a very particular kind of hurt: the sort that keeps a spoon next to a photograph on a windowsill and pretends the arrangement will hold back time. She found the bone with her other hand and slid its smile into the stabler’s mouth and kept it there as if they might reassure each other, and then she did something she disliked: she spoke of herself in public. “I know a separation that needed doing,” she said, not looking at Bram because then she wouldn’t say it. “It was a cough once. It had its own music and its own manners and we had taught it into our afternoons. I took it away, and a man was left with his breath and without his punctuation and he discovered that he needed to learn another kind of noise for his own door. You are not offering that kind of mercy. You are offering to unfasten anything that makes us feel obliged to each other. That is not truth. That is a loneliness you want company for.”

He did not scowl because men like him never have scowled in public; they have learned better tricks. He hissed at the map’s title, which was the name of the city in a hand that had known nothing of wolves and a great deal of rain, and the letters twitched because pride is vulnerable under certain lights. Mara lifted the stabler and closed it not on the paper this time but on the sound of Hesta’s own name as it had been spoken a hundred times by men who did not mean it and a dozen times by women who did. She stapled that sound to the map’s title and felt the paper settle as if countries, too, are relieved to be reminded of who they are by someone who calls them by their right diminutives. Hesta’s mouth quirked to one side because she had not said thank you in a long time for anyone fastening her in a place she would have chosen.

They might have played the Registry like an organ until noon and perhaps the wrong would have gotten bored and left to find a wall to scold, but the man with the hiss did the one thing that changed the day into a story Mara would have to tell carefully if she did not want to make a habit of fear. He turned the device not on paper, not on wood, but on a woman’s hand as it rested on the edge of the drawer she had learned as a young clerk with a ribbon in her hair. He fit the mouth around her thumb and drew down, and the jaw kissed the skin and exhaled, and the drawer forgot it had been hers for thirty years, and the woman forgot which side of the counter she belonged on, and the wrong discovered a new appetite in the room and wagged its tail. She swayed and looked at her hand like it had missed a step and taken her with it. “No,” Mara said, and her voice had iron in it because you can talk stone into good behavior if you find the patient vowels, and she crossed the space as Hesta did and Tamsin did and Bram did, and for a second they were a fence.

Mara put the stabler’s open jaw on the space between the woman’s thumb and the drawer, not on flesh and not on wood but on the memory that lay there like an old penny, of having once cut that thumb on a paper edge and bled a little and licked the wound and finished writing anyway. She closed her hand and felt the sigh go into a tiny, polite place, and the drawer remembered it liked being touched by someone who kept it clean, and the woman remembered the drawer was hers for another year unless she said otherwise, and the wrong lost interest in that seam because it was not famous enough to bother with. Hesta took the woman’s wrist and tied a thread that had already had a hundred wrists remember themselves with its help, and the woman sat in a chair like a throne and held her hand like a baby and whispered obscene things at the man with the hiss because there are obscenities that are as useful as prayers.

“Enough,” Corwin said, and there was no pen in his hand and he had never sounded more like a citizen and less like an official. “Hesta, arrest him. Tamsin, if that device has a seam, you will show Mara where it is. Bram, if there is a whistle that makes a man reconsider his allegiance to romance, I would be obliged to hear it.” He looked at the hiss with a hunger he did not pretend to have permission for and then looked at Mara and let the hunger turn into trust, which is the best trick he knows. “Do not kill him. He is a person. Do not keep him. He is a person. Do not let him walk away with the city’s vocabulary in his pocket.”

The man did not run because he believed the allure of the clean unbinding would be enough to make them give him a corridor to leave by, and because he had moved through rooms like this in three other towns and been thanked afterward for the clarity he had provided when houses remembered they had stoves and did not need tables. Hesta did not reach for cuffs because there are moments when you must not confess to a wrong that it has the proportions of a crime; she reached for the woman’s hand again and she reached for Mara’s shoulder and she reached for the edge of the map, and in making those three gestures in one body she made a force that ignored the hiss and did not require it to be impressed.

Tamsin took the thread from her wrist and laid it along the mouth of the device without touching it, and the thread thrummed in a note Mara had begun to recognize as older than any Council. “It wants to learn a song,” Tamsin said, amused in that furious way that makes children behave out of respect for a tone. “If you teach it a song, it will have to sing it before it can hiss again and the song will take time and we have time enough to be wise if we are not greedy. It has learned only one tune. It thinks it is an art to undo what is badly done even when the thing that was badly done has learned, from being badly done, to be useful.”

Bram whistled something like the old morning call to lambs that had pulled their heads out of their mothers’ flanks and were uncertain about being persons, and the hiss quivered and adjusted its mouth because a device that exists to teach a thing how to leave home is romantically susceptible to any tone that promises it could be part of a flock. Mara did a foolish thing and she will be forgiven later or she will not; she put the stabler and the bone together and bit down on the rim of the hiss’s jaw with her own tool and pressed with a patient impertinence until the sigh laid itself across the hiss like a blanket and flattened it and took away its cleverness for the length of one breath. In that breath Hesta’s hand came down not with a cuff but with a strip of leather she had used once to tie a door open at a birth, and she wrapped it around the hiss and the man’s wrist and made them each other’s problem.

He looked more frightened by that than by the threat of law. “You cannot tether me to my device,” he said, which was the truest thing he had said since he came, and Tamsin smiled like a woman who knows ten different names for weather and the way each makes the bread rise. “Oh, we can,” she said. “You have been telling it what you are for a week. Let it tell you. Let it ask you whether it really wanted to separate a woman’s hand from her work. Let it hiss at your knuckles until you hear yourself. It will not hurt. It will be worse than pain. It will be instructive.”

Hesta took him, not to a cell but to a chair in the corridor where a draft sits out its days, and set the chair in a circle she drew on the floor at knees and ankles and wrists because circles do their best thinking when they can find elbows to lean on, and she told him not to move and he did not because the hiss had become heavy in his hand with all the unfastenings he had asked of it and was asking if he might like some of his own seams untidied for a change. Corwin sat on the corner of the Registry table like a boy and rubbed his eyes with the heel of a hand that had not learned to tolerate tears and said, “We will not have one of those in this city. I do not care if they send me six letters with seals on them that cost a goat each. Put the word out: if you see a hiss, call it by its bad name, which is Separator, and if the man holding it looks like the kind of person who asks for more rope than he needs, send him to me and I will put him in a chair with Hesta’s circles and we will give him soup until his device chooses to refuse him.”

Mara put the map back and smoothed its corners and put her hand on the place where her part of town lay, a smudge of streets and courtyards and the small, obstinate lines people call lives. The stabler was warm, very warm, and the bone had that smug temperature that says somebody has learned something at last. She leaned against the edge of the table and felt all of her ages in her back, and Bram leaned next to her in the way of men who would like to be a stick but have been given the burden of skin, and they watched as the Registry remembered how to be one room and not several.

They had a day and a half after that when nothing resorted to devices but everything had the hum that follows a public wrong the way bees hang around a shirt that once smelled of honey. The city behaved with a politeness that felt like exhaustion and remembered how to salt its soup and share its weather and take notes. The sheep did the extraordinary thing of making no special arrangements at the bell fence, which oddly reassured everyone more than if they had lined up and performed; they pressed their ears to iron and to earth, not to listen for wolves this time but to listen for the thing that comes after a hiss has been in a room and left its opinion on the chairs.

At twilight on the second day, someone knocked on Mara’s door without knocking, which is to say the house knew who was at the threshold and opened itself a little out of habit. The man with the cough stood in the hallway, hat in hand, hat in the sense of humility and hat in the sense of the actual object, and his face had that look of having been re-arranged by air and regret and coming willingly to be admitted to the number of the living. He did not look like a wizard because there are no wizards; he looked like a person who had been too proud of his hands and had gone to a hill to be scolded, and the hill had been efficient. “You may hit me,” he said without preamble that would have flattered him, “for sending you a thing without a letter with more verbs in it, and you may feed me, and I will accept whichever you choose as the correct order.”

She did neither at once. She pointed at the sink where the stabler lay and at the table where the bone and the letter and the wool were piled in that particular geometry that arises when you live alone and love too many objects. He put his hat down and his cough behaved in a way that told her he had made peace with his throat and its desire to have its own punctuation. “It is more beautiful than I remembered,” he said, which is always the right thing to say about a tool. “It gets that sheen when it has been used for what it was meant for. If you had been cruel with it, it would be duller and you would be thinner and your eyes would be worse at noticing rooms.”
